description: White or horizontally striped stockings on right. On left are flesh-colored or white stockings with fishnet over-stockings for a young girl (or even a wealthy little boy with his fancy dress). Long pantalets might be gathered at the ankle, or tubular with tucking or lace edging.
source: Carma drew these after Lynne Wilson’s Shoe Fashions and from Charles Dickens’ illustrator, George Cruikshank.

caption: Drawings of representative shoes from the 1840s through 1860s.
description: Left: low-heeled oxford, much worn, poorly dyed black. Oxfords on left were for both boys and girls and farmwomen. Many aged oxfords were encountered as curators in Cooperstown, New York, prepared a display in the Farmer’s Museum. Right: Fancy cutout bootee with elastic sides is for women. Multi-colors show under the shapes of the cutouts. These are square-toed from the 1840s to 60s.
source: Drawings by Carma from Farmers Museum, Cooperstown, New York. Free use. Many more shoes from the 1800s may be seen in A History of Shoe Fashions by Eunice Wilson, Pitman Press 1969.

caption: Home-made dresses on young sisters, 1840s
description: Two girls between 8 and 10 wear matching clothing: blue cotton dresses gathered in at the waistline with belts. Diagonal tucks in the sleeves appear almost as cap sleeves over elbow-length sleeves. Sleeves and neckline have a little trim of lace. Long pantalets of white and pale blue are trimmed with a bit of lace, and reach down to black, squaretoed booties that lace up the inside. Center parted hair is drawn back into either a braid or a smallbun. Each carries a small basket or bouquet of flowers
source: “Children of the Young Republic” in American Heritage April 1960.

caption: Finer dresses of 1845 in folk-art painting of Anna Gould Crane and granddaughter, Janette Young.
description: Janette wears a yellow, calico print dress with tiny red sprigs, and has simple tubes for pantalets. Her little chemisette barely shows at the neckline of her wrap-over bodice. Curls fall over her shoulders onto her bodice. White stockings and flat black shoes are greatly exaggerated as elegantly (and inhumanly) small. Grandmother Anna has a perfectly smooth, white, neck shawl pinned over the shoulders of her black, fullskirted dress. In folk-art style, her head is over-large, with a very meager day cap. One foot showing is the size of a finger. This painting has a faux frame painted around the edge of the stretched canvas.
source: Oil on canvas by Sheldon Peck, Aurora, Illinois. Seen in book, American Radiance: The Ralph Esmerian Gift to the American Folk Art Museum. (New York, Harry N. Abrams, Inc. 2001)

caption: Girl in a flounced blue dress of 1840s seen on a tinted Postcard.
description: Flounced blue dress on a girl of 1840s from a tinted Postcard, A young girl wears a pale blue dress with a flounced skirt. Three pleats on her shoulder seams are anchored in a V at her waistline. She seems to have bell sleeves with matching engageants below. Her straight hair, parted in the middle, is fastened in back with a large black bow. Originally a sepia-toned daguerreotype, this image looks more realistic with tinting.
source: A loose tinted postcard with no artist listed, Purchased at J. Paul Getty Museum, printed by Chronicle Books, 1200 Getty Center Dr., Los Angeles, CA 90049.

caption: Adolescent girl carrying her basket-purse, standing beside her bonnet, ca. 1848-58.
description: dress. It is of brown and white checks with an overhanging peplum and a small white lace collar. One inch wide brown ribbons edged in white reach from the middle of her shoulders down to the peplum, where they form a border. Narrow sleeves are cut on the bias and flare out over her forearms with two lines of ribbon for decoration. Narrow engageants are pure white batiste to the wrists. She wears a short string of (possibly) gold beads, and tiny, ball earrings. Her yellow straw bonnet with wide white ribbons lies on a table beside her. It has ruching on the brim's edge. Her unique purse is a tiny, footed, basket-shape with two loop handles.
source: A loose tinted postcard with no artist listed, Purchased at J. Paul Getty Museum, printed by Chronicle Books, 1200 Getty Center Dr., Los Angeles, CA 90049.

caption: Connected bodice and drawers for little child of 3 - 4, ca. 1830 to 1850.
description: Best cotton muslin makes underwear for a fast-growing toddler or little child of either gender. Top and bottoms are connected with buttons, and a drop-down flap in back (indicated by placket openings on each side seam) would be essential for using any type of potty chair. Pretty tucks and lace decorate the hems.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Double layer apron for a little girl, ca. late-1840s on.
description: Two layers of strong cotton, one shorter than the other, were from early pioneer times in Utah. The entire waistband and ties are a long strip of cotton, woven tape. If a little girl were helping with the washing it might be good to have double layers of the apron to keep her dress dry in the primitive methods of wooden tub washing and sloshing.
source: Source: The apron came in a bundle of donations to Carma’s collection. The family was no longer interested in storing clothes from far past family as they downsized their home. Photo by Carma; free use

caption: Mourning bonnet for a little girl, ca. 1845.
description: It is assumed that because this bonnet is solid black, it was a mourning bonnet. It is made of braided straw with a lining of silk. Many decades ago this bonnet was seen by Carma in Nauvoo, Illinois in the John Taylor Home. It is supposed to be the bonnet of Taylor’s little daughter.
source: Photographed by Vicky L. Boyack Clarke. Black ribbon ties were drawn on the Photo afterward by Carma. Free use.

caption: Girl’s lace-up shoe, 1840s, from Vienna, Austria
description: Soft suede leather lined in kid leather with ankle bands in a very small dotted print. Cord lacing is in holes center front, with multi-looped rosette at bottom of lacing. Thin leather soles have an extra layer for the heel. Similar shoes all over Europe, Britain, and America.
source: Drawn by Carma after Margo Lister, Costumes of Everyday Life. Free use.

caption: Girl's dressy shoes of mixed fabric in dull green, ca.1840s-70s.
description: Probably a mixture of woven silk and wool make up the outside of the strap-and-button shoes. Layered and lined in linen with slightly squared toes. The button to close the strap is positioned on the top of the foot, not the side.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum, drawn by Margaret Weber. Free use.

caption: Porcelain headed doll with ringlets wears the remnants of a red dress, 1840s.
description: This doll has a lovely painted face and shiny black clusters of ringlets on each side of her head, as was popular from the 1830s to 60s. Her porcelain neck and shoulders extend past a wide dress neckline, beneath which is a soft, stuffed body. The arms and legs are simply stuffed tubes of cloth. Originally, her dress would have been ornate and long-sleeved. But when the original wore out, this red cotton-flannel dress replaced it. Even so, the red flannel is much worn in the front bodice from much handling and love.
source: LDS Museum of Church History and Art in Salt Lake City. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Fashion Doll of 1840s with porcelain head.
description: This pink silk dress has petticoats beneath, and a jacket edged with pink, dyed linen lace. Her bonnet is woven of rosy pink ribbons. The sleeves are elbow length, but the porcelain arms were probably broken off by the John Taylor children.
source: The doll resides in the John Taylor home restored in Nauvoo, Illinois. Photo by Vikki L. Boyak Clarke. Free use.

caption: A carved wooden doll representing Queen Mary, ca. 1840.
description: The doll's head is a smooth eggshape with painted features. Her brown, painted hair shows around her face, but she seems to have a painted black cap covering the rest of her head. A large gold comb rises from the area where a woman would wear a bun. Her sleeve tops are fully gathered, but narrow down to slender wrists with a bias self-binding. The skirt is in two parts: the flared overskirt is cut on the straight grain, but the underskirt, showing in an inverted V, is cut on the cross-grain. We see pleating in the bodice angling down to the waistline, as was so fashionable in most 1840s dresses.
source: This antique doll was found in Lehi, Utah. Carma made an authentic-styled dress to be photographed on an original quilt for the Ensign Magazine.

caption: Farmers still wore work smocksand trousers. 1800 –1900on.
description: A Farmer in New York, David Whitmerwears the usual American linen smock to cover his clothing while working. If the day were hot, a farmer might wear nothing on his torso except his tough linen smock. He also wears a broad-brimmed, low crowned hat and heavy leather work shoes. David's family hosted Joseph Smith, Jr. for one month while the Prophet used this safe place to get away from life-threatening mobs while translating the Book of Mormonfrom ancient gold plates into English. Details of Smock construction can be found in 1800-1820.
source: This ink drawing, a portrait by Robert Barrett, is displayed in the Grandin Print Shop, Palmyra, New York. The clothing was carefully coached by Carma for the artist. Photo by Carma; free use

caption: 1850s Vest and cap worn by a talented African-American farmhand, ca. 1850s.
description: This young man working as a servant on Stony Brook farm in Long Island, New York, when it was completely rural.  He has time to cheerfully play his banjo, making wonderful music for all to enjoy.The Mount family kept no slaves. He wears a beige vest with colored, striped lapels edged by gold silk, with red silk fabric for the back. His neckerchief is an edge-striped light red silk. Dark wool pants are horizontally buttoned across the front in a "broad-fall." A string around his neck has a small, gold stick fob. He appears to have a gold chain leading to a vest pocket which has a blue handkerchief and might contain a watch. His pointed cap which flops over at the top is of horizontal knitted black and red stripes.
source: Painting by William Sidney Mount. Seen in: David Cassidy and Gail Shrott, Janice Gray Armstrong, Ed. William Sidney Mount, Works in the Collection of The Museum at Stony Brook. (The Museums at Stony Brook, Stony Brook N.Y. 1983).

caption: 1850s  Father and son cut logs into planks.
description: On left is a raw log, half sawed, with a 2-man saw and an ax in front.Father wears a vest over warm, striped sweater.  Striped trousers. He has a pilot’s cap and a kerchief tied around his neck.Father and son both wear work boots.His facial hair has muttonchops and a beard, and his hair is neck length.Son’s jacket is torn and falling apart, but still gives warmth. Sleeve ripped, buttons few. He also wears a pilot cap, later called anewsboys cap.
source: Woodsawyer's Nooning, Getty Museum.Freeuse.

caption: 1854 warm wool coat and boots areneeded while fishing through the ice,
description: This warm, wool, double-breasted coat is lined with red plaid wool. It has leather buttons and pocket flaps and is held at his waist with a red sash, most likely the sash worn with his local militia uniform in upstate N.Y.Light brown gloves keep his hands warm.He has knee-high leather boots over brown wool trousers.His hat is a felt Stetson with a brown string around the crown. Facial hair is mutton-chop whiskers, and possibly a beard under his chin.
source: Fishing Through the Ice, a painting by Arthur Fitzwilliam Tate, 1854, 'American Heritage' August 1969.

caption: 1856 American Hunting Camp in the Adirondacks
description: A party of American hunters and campers relax in the very large oil painting. They wearwool shirts in red, black, gray,and white, and one man has a light jacket.They have a variety of hats from a straw boater (back) to bent-up Stetsons, and the man on the right wears a hat similar to a railroad cap. All wear boots and trousers. Facial hair ranges from a mustache and Van Dyke beards to large muttonchops, under-chin beards, and one clean-shaven.The men have made a lean-to from broken trees covered with slabs of bark.
source: By Frederick Rondel, 1856, Camp in the Adirondacksin 'American Heritage' August 1969.

caption: Mid-1800s Lumberjack shows the relative circumference of old-growth trees in Minnesota.
description: The mid-1800s was an activetime for lumbering in the big forests of northern states. Almost any healthyman could get a job with meals and rough housing.Men wore wool shirts and knee-high bootsinside or outside of wool trousers. They always wore hats outdoors.Here we see a man with a beard and mustache.
source: By Holzhuber, in 'American Heritage' June 1965

caption: 1859, A lumberjack and his supervisor in Minnesota forests.
description: Mid-1800s werean active time for lumbering in the big forests of northern states. Almost any healthyman could get a job with hefty meals and rough housing.Men wore wool shirts and trousers with knee-high bootsworn under or over trousers. They always wore hats outdoors.Thesemen wearbeards and mustaches.
source: By Holzhuber, in 'American Heritage' June 1965

caption: Workmen in roughclothingare cleaning a sewer. Mid-1800s on.
description: Most of these men wear heavy leather boots treated to bewater-resistant, or later, rubber boots. Their clothing is hard-usedand ill-fitting.  Many wear underwear as a shirt, sometimes with jackets over the top.  They have crushed hats and caps of all kinds.These are the lowest of the low-class.
source: Source has been lost, and this was the only image we were able tosave.

caption: 1850 Levi Strauss, Bavarian, fabric dealer, of San Francisco,invents “Levis” of denim with rivets.
description: Your favorite jeans are named after a Jewish German immigrantfrom Buttenheim, Germany. Levi Straussfled to New York at 18to escape repressive laws against Jews. He moved to San Francisco in 1820 to start a wholesale dry goods business, selling everything from purses to bedding. His business thrived for 20 years before his famouspants were born.Strauss met Jacob Davis, a tailor from Reno, Nevada, They joined to create and patent the first blue jean of riveted denim. Double stitching, plus copper rivets at stress points, kept their jeansfrom ripping and made them stronger and more secure.(Illustration is a later brand.)
source: 'The Forty-Niners'' Time-Life Books. Info from website levi.com/US/en_US/blog/article/born-out-west/

caption: 1840-80s Cowboys throughout the US west.
description: Cowboys were men who drove cattle across wide ranges to grass and waterand later to the rail yards for shipping to slaughterhouses. Glamorized in fiction, they led hard, rough lives, sleeping outdoors and riding horses all of most days.The most casual of dressers in the mid to late 1800s, they worelong-sleeved shirtsagainst weather and sunburn, sometimes with vests. Neckerchiefs were much used to cover the mouth and nose during dust-storms and the dust kicked up by moving cattle.Denim jeans, invented by Levi Strauss forGold Rush miners were favorite trousers because they were tough fabric, double-stitched, and reinforced at all stress points with metal rivets.  Over the jeans,they often wore leather chaps, which protected their legs from wild growth, as they rode and worked.One man here has gloves, though all would have used them, and a few have guns for shooting at preditors of four and two legs. Most cowboyssmoked.Hats were wide and flat-brimmed to block harsh sunlight but were bent into any shapethe men wanted. They wore “cowboy boots”with pointed toes to slip easily into stirrups, and heels to keep the boots from sliding too far forwardMany wore mustaches, but beards were too hot in the summer sun.Cowboys are still needed today, are just as rugged, and dress pretty much the same way.
source: From thelastbestwest.com

caption: 1850, a pair of brothers relax after a day of mining for gold in California.
description: Both men wear typical, drop-shoulder shirts, one with a buttoned neckband and an overshirt buttoned belowthe waist. Long sleeves are gathered at the cuffed wrists.Waist-high trousers have the newer front opening, and hems are rolled up over bare feet.  Likely, they have been wading in streams while panning for the yellow metal.  One wears suspenders while the other wears a mustache and chin beard. Their blond hair is short and side-parted. The left brother has such light blue eyes they are barely visible.A gold pan and a broad-brimmed straw hat can be seen behind their legs.
source: picture has been lost but is searchable online under California gold miners.

caption: 1850 Auction of livestock in America, rich and poorattend.
description: An auction in a farming community draws many levels of society. Some men wear fine clothing, while others wear shirt sleeves or work smocks. Hats include toppers, straw hats, and broad-brimmed farmers' hats.
source: Altered by Carma from Grafton, Trades And Occupations

caption: Wooden leg made and worn by John Rowe Moyle, stonemason in Utah Territory, ca. 1855.
description: This is the wood and leather leg carved by John while recovered from losing his right leg in a bone-shattering accident when a cow kicked him. With no anesthetics, his lower leg was amputated. Yet somehow he healed! Afterward,John persisted in walking 22 miles every Monday morning from Alpine, UT to work on the Salt Lake Temple. Then he walked back to Alpine for the weekends with his family. For several years he cut granite stone into measured blocks. He also carved lettering into the granite on theupper east-end of the temple: “THE SALT LAKE TEMPLETHE HOUSE OF THE LORD(painted afterward in gold).
source: Wooden leg in Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Free use.

caption: 1850s working women, Possibly garment factory since some have scissors.
description: They may haveaprons overtheirdresses, or these could be skirts and tucked-in blouses.  Hairistypicalwith acenter partandswagsof hairpoofed over the earswithbuns in back.One woman has waves and hanging curls.
source: Found online:working women, Repository Unknown, Google, 1850 working women.

caption: Mormon handcarts through Iowa, a wood engraving, ca. 1856.
description: The foremost woman is wearing a short gown over her long skirt, as is the woman on far right.  Her shoes are flats, not boots because they had only their fashionable shoes left to wear when sturdier shoes wore out. She has a wide straw hat to shade her from the sun as she pulls her load of possessions. Her toddler is riding on top of the load while another woman pushes the cart from behind.  Canvas covers over their goods were sometimes used as tents overnight in bad weather.Behind her,a man pulls his own handcart as he enthusiastically waves to the people along the way. He wears high boots and a long-sleeved shirt, probably wool.  He has a long British mustache.  Other families walk along beside them carrying babies and leading little children as young as 5 and 6 years old.  Very small children actually walked all the way to the Rocky Mountains, as recorded in reminiscences. According to some pioneer diaries, many people in larger populations called out ridicule atthe travelers as they passed.
source: Common image in public domain.

caption: Plain working woman, 1859.
description: This light-colored dress has a bodice closed by white shell buttons --one missing. Sleevecaplets top long gathered sleeves with buttoned cuffs. Six vertical darts narrow the bodice of the dress, though she wears no corset. The white scalloped collar may be attached to the dress or tied around her neck. Her day cap shows minimal ruching aroundher face with narrow ties under the chin. The gathered apron is figured with little clusters of flowers on a dark background.
source: Daguerreotype by Joseph Covais 1859.  From Joan L. Severa, Dressed for the Photographer,  Ordinary Americans andFashion 1840 -1900, (Kent, Ohio, Kent State University, 1995).

caption: Original American settler couple considers selling land to a German, ca. 1850.
description: An original settlerhusband has longer, unkempt hair and beard. His shawl-collared vest is extra-long and not buttoned. His wife wears aplain day dress and long apron, her hair in a long back braid.An enterprising German is a buyer ofimproved lands.In a narrow-sleeved frockcoat and a fine, low-crowned, bowler hat,he bargains with original settlerswho have put much labor into their land. His long trousers are a lighter color than his fashionably darker, straight-hanging box coat. He has a finely trimmed black beard.
source: Frederic Troutman, Missouri Historical Review, 1983, Missouri State Historical Society, Missouri State University. Free use.

caption: English chair-seat maker with wife bringing rushes to him.
description: This balding working man wears knee-breeches with stockings and buckled shoes from earlier years. No vest is seen but would be worn. He is sitting on the ground in dry weather weaving chair seats, a common type of furniture for speed of production or for a poor-class market. His wife brings hima bundle of marsh rushes on her back and holds her cutting knife. She wears dark stockings and shoes. Her skirt back is shortened by the load she carries. She doesn’t seem to be wearing many petticoats beneath her old woolen skirt. A shawl is tied securely around her upper body, protecting her from both the weather and her burden. Sheis carrying some load in her white apron. Her hat is probably a worn-out felt with a small brim.
source: From a trades book of 1850.  Specific source for this illustration has been lost, but it is public domain.

caption: A free African-American family prior to the Civil War.
description: This neatly dressed, middle-class family shows care in dressing.  Father has a plain wool coat buttoned at the neck with a small collar. Mother has a dark-colored dress with a small white collar, and  ¾ length flared sleeves, but no engageants. Her bonnet hasdarkinner ruffles, a bow near the top, and long ribbon ties under the chin.  Two girls wear matching flowered dresses and straw hats with flowers on top. Their matching coats are a light color.
source: Found on Google, 1800s Working Women.

caption: 1850s-60s FAMILY Emigrants from many countries launch from Liverpoolto America.
description: Left to right, a woman has a long plaid cloak over her shoulder, a warm folk cap, and possessions tied around her waist. A man is in breeches and thick stockingsin a disheveled tailcoat and old straw hat. A wealthier man in a fine pale tailcoat and black topper speaks with a man sitting on a piece of luggage.  On a strong wooden trunk beside him is another man in a cream wool coat and light felt topper. Two youngmen standing behind them wear an old topper and a tam o'shanter cap.  The man the cream holds a walking stick and faces a group of mothers with children all bundled in warm clothes. One woman has a plaid shawl and a shallow bonnet and sits just below thetipped carrier cart. At far right by the white horse is a man in light tan trousers, probably a red vest and a brown coat. He faces a small girl in a plaid shawl. We can only see the back of her round-crowned bonnet. Foreground, a young boy in light stockings huddles close to his family’s bundles for a nap, ignoring the big horse only inches away. These emigrants often had a leader among each nationality who could speak English a bit (especially among the Church of Jesus Christ LDS) to translatetheir needs as a group. The strong wooden boxes and large trunks still in the cart, covered with a tied-down canvas, contain everything from tools of their trades to clothing andprecious belongings.  Strong cloth bags and belongings wrapped in blankets suffice for the poorer classesMostly, it wasEnglish emigrants who left for America from Liverpool, but some Scandinavian, French, Swiss,or Italians also went to Liverpool and mixed with other Church of Jesus Christ memberswho spoke many different languages. The Scots couldn't understand the French and the Germans, and Danes couldn't do much with English--yet.
source: Illustration done at the time of emigration, from Mary Bywater Cross, Quilts and Women of the Migrations, Treasures of Transitions, (Rutledge Hill Press, 1997),Permission from Lindsley Leslie, given to Carma earlier.

caption: 1850s Best dressed men in a fashion plate.Styles were standard for middle and upper-classes, but fabric and ornamentation differed.
description: Coats have tails or skirts, and the button front is not buttoned but shows the fancy vests.  Coat collars are medium-wide, with and without notches. Plaids and checks were popular, so the man on the right has a checkered lining that extends to the lapels and cuffs.Waistcoats, now called vests,were ornate in fabric and décor and often had lapels of their own. Shirts had smaller collars which sometimes foldedover the smaller neckties.Queen Victoria was wild about plaids, so plaid trousers (and ladies’ dresses)became ubiquitous. Center man has buttoned tabs as ornaments down his trouserside seamsFacial hair came in a hundred styles of mustaches, beards,and muttonchop whiskers.Taller tophats were in fashion.Shoes had square toes and were illustratedas being tiny to show “refinement.  The general style was maintainedby all, but fabric quality and décor degraded as cost went down.Even the poor tried for some style but may have had to buy 2ndor 3rd-hand clothing.
source: Found on 1850s Men clothing, Pinterest.

caption: 1850s men’s fashion plate, with one boy.
description: Men’s upper torsowas often padded to show a “pouter pigeon profile,” rounded from breast to waistline.Special corsets might be worn to enhance this look.Coats were well fitted, with snugwaist and straight sleeves, oftenwith cuffs. Lapels could be rounded or sharply angled but had buttonholes to the collar, though never used. A trim binding was popular. Waistcoats cut straight across the waistline. Man on left has an ornately trimmed back coat vent.Shirtshad small collars to wear up or folded over smaller ties or cravats.Trousers were straight-legged, but often with ornamentation on the outer seam. They might be a fall front styleor open in center front.Tophats might be in several mutations of style in height and brim. Muttonchopwhiskers are on these men. The boy wears a pilot's cap with ribbons, a coat with elaborate braid trim, pagoda sleeves, and either a long-sleeved shirt with fully gathered sleeves or engageants. Thesegeneral styles wereworn by all classes, but the fabricwas finer,and décor wasgreater on the clothing of the wealthy.

caption: 1854 The English mode ofmatching“suit”on Samuel W. Richards.
description: While not perfectly clear in this daguerreotype, the coat, waistcoat,and trousers areall of the same fabric. Such matching items werecalled a “suit.” In this image, his overcoat is of a different fabric. Until the 1850s, all three men’s items were made of different colors and types of fabrics as seen in formerdecades.  We see a long watch-chain draped across his waist.His collar is folded over a straight square-knot tie.Hairstyles were still long at the back of the neck, usually parted on the side, and some sort of facial hair was chosen by individual men.  Samuel, here, wears athick, 2-3 inch beard on his lower chin, but no mustache.While posing for the photographer, a stand was positionedbehind the subject, and a clamp was placed on the back of the subject’shead or neck to hold himsteady toprevent blurring.  One can see the stand directly behind his feet.That’s also why subjects didn’t smilesince it took from one to 3 minutes of exposure for one image plate, and smiles are hard to hold without motion for that long.

caption: 1859 Photographer with beard, mustache,and sack (sacque) coat in hisstudio.
description: This tall man is wearing a long coat, which is not fitted to the shape of his body but has the narrower sleeves of the 1850s.  Around the lapels, hem,and welt pockets of his coat are bandsof silk tape trim.His glorious new camera is a prizedpossession (so different than daguerreotype equipment!) and can simply be mounted on a tripod, ready for a client to be immortalized instantly in a true image. The photographer can employ outdoor forms of light to create reproducible photos. (Note the scenic background painting and rock terrace in front. )
source: Bancroft Library (#1905. 16242)University of California, Berkeley.From Joan Severa, Dressed for the Photographer,1995.

caption: 1850s Men's short, caped paletots in two styles, buttonsdown the front 1854; cloak with arm slits 1852, Cunnington
description: A “paletot” is, strictly speaking, a double-breasted overcoat for men or women featuring a lapel, though other variations were also called paletots. The two above are capedpaletots thatbutton down the front. The left style has no arm slits, but the upper cloak of the two lengths allows an arm to reach out from beneath. On right is a paletot with distinct arm slits and a velvet or satin collar. Both paletots and trousers are made of wooltweeds and checks.
source: Cunnington. Public Domain

caption: Men’s long frock coat, usually in wool broadcloth or cheaper wool, or in heavy linen for summer.  Ca. 1830s -1850s.
description: A frock coat is so-called because, like a woman’s frock,  ithas a complete skirt attached to the fitted waistline.  It could be as short as the knees in the earlier 1800s, but later, most fell to calf length.Any wool coat had a full lining of silk in the body or cambric in printed colors in the sleeve. Linen coats for summer had little lining.The center-back vent is slit to the waist with the right side over lapping the left about two inches, and decorative buttons at the waistline. The high back slit in the coat skirt enables riding a horse or driving a team from a wooden seat. Strong muslin pockets hang inside at the waistline seam and have outside flaps .A welt pocket is on the left breast. Sometimes there were deep interior breast pocketsfor documents. Sleeves are cut in two pieces, upper and lower portions, so they fit very well.  Buttons were of metal or bone.
source: Carma's design and drawing for a historic reenactment. Free use.

caption: This opera singer highlights the sartorial preferences of stylishgentlemen during the late 1850s.
description: Most notable is hisfancy silk vestwith wide lapels,  a bold pattern,and metal buttons. This reflected the general delight with bold patternsin clothing during the latter part of this decade. A watch chain drapes below his vest.His frockcoat has a wide velvet collar and turned up sleeves.The lapels have buttonholes to the top, which are for design only, and are never used. His hairstyle hasa high part and is brushed smoothly. His cravat, barely seen, is tied as a soft silk ascot. Facial hair includes a well-trimmed mustache and beard, but only the scantiest sideburns He is not holding a cell phone.

caption: Apothecary / Pharmacist, Henry Brewer, mixes medicines, ca. 1850.
description: Working with mortar and pestle to grind minerals and herbs according to a well-known formulary, Brewer wears a linen/cotton checkered coat with narrow, turned-up one-button cuffs. A washable apron of tiny gingham cloth is spread on his lap and legs. His starched collar, black tie,and pale-colored vest show that he is a very respectable, middle-class citizen.
source: Beaumont Newhall, The Daguerreotype in America, (New York, Dover Publications Inc. 3rd revised ed., 1961).

caption: A musician tunes his violin for a homeentertainment, ca. 1840-1850.
description: The Mount family enjoyed many relaxed music times. This Mount brother wears a felt hat with an upward curved brim and a 4 “ high crown. His loose shirt hasa soft, silky tie knotted casually, andcuffs are seen at the unbuttoned wrists of his coat. The coat is tobacco-colored wool with loose, wide lapels and binding around the collar. A faint jawline beard mirrors his thin mustache.His chin-length hair curls naturally.The Mounts' large family had many friends and were constantly promoting music and dancing on rural Long Island in 1840s, New York.  William Sydney Mount was so clever in his wealthy farm family, that he invented and made his own violin, a very strangely shallow instrument.
source: “Just in Tune” is an oil portrait by William Sydney Mount seen in the book by Alfred Frankenstein, Painter of Rural America, William Sidney Mount, 1807-1868.(The Suffolk Museum at Stony Brook, Long Island, New York, 1968).

caption: A hunter and gentlemen farmerdiscuss news from paper.1853.
description: Bothfelt hats are excellent examples of natural, pale wool felt and black felt, usually mixed with some animal fur to give them a sheen, and pressed into shape on molds. The edges of both hat brims are rolled upward. The man ontheleftwears a red silk vest below a short chin beard and mustache. His trousers are wool with a double, green, vertical stripe every few inches. His low-heeled boots are almost covered by his trousers. A long rifle leans against a fence post beside a bird he has shot.The man ontherightwho listens to the news wears an olive vest, possibly corded silk, and a redand yellow stripedneckerchief,and a heavy brown wool coat down to his knees. He carries a 2 pronged pitchfork for farm work.
source: Painting,The Herald in the Country, by W. S. Mount, 1853. Found in David Cassidy and Gail Shrott, Janice Gray Armstrong, Ed. William Sidney Mount, Works in the Collection of The Museum at Stony Brook. (The Museums at Stony Brook, Stony Brook N.Y. 1983 ) Also seen online.

caption: Quaker young man, ca. 1850
description: The Quakers were a religion that renounced any fashion that promoted vanity.  Having buttons and buttonholes had often been a sign of wealth and fashion, sowere therefore not puton coats.  This coat does have a collar and cuff, which must have been seen as essential for warmth.Trousers might have a button for closure, that being “essential.” Zippers were not adopted after their invention. Hats would usually have a wide, flat, brim, and could have a flat-topped crown, or a slightly conical crown, but no fancy bands, buckles,or ornamentation. Brims could be bent up or down as desired.
source: Illustration after C.W. Trout.

caption: American policeman arrestsa criminal. Both wear box coats without curved seams or darts to fit the figure, ca.  1845-60.
description: Both box coats have straight lines in front and back with very minimal fitting. The officer has a velvet collar with a binding ofthe same wool as the coat. Itis cut straight across the bottom and hangs to mid-thigh. The coat buttons high on his chest, and has welt side pockets. Sleeves are comfortably wide. Undoubtedly it has a warm lining for changing weather. Policeman’s trousers have broad crossbars woven into the fabricand are floor-length. Each man’s top hat is somewhatcaved-in on top.  Thispoliceman wears a short, full beardonly on and below his chin, with no mustache.
source: Courtesy of American Antiquarian Society, Worcester, Massachusetts.

caption: Levi Gregory Metcalf, a Mormonpioneer came to the Utah Territory in 1858.
description: This early form of photography shows a man with very pale eyes and a small chin beard. His hair was blunt cut at back-collar length. A sturdy felt hat with brim of five inches was wrapped with an old neckerchief which hangs loosely from a knot on the side. Beneath his shirt collar of tiny checkered fabric, he has wrapped a much used and wrinkled neckerchief tied in a square knot. His coat, which seems of lightweight wool, is much outgrown and tight across his chest, with large, flat, cloth-covered [wooden] buttons. His right breast pocket on the coat shows too much of his wrinkled white handkerchief draped from it. That handkerchief had been an aid to his poor nose and eyes through dusty wheels of traveling in wagons, or plowing windy fields.  His two-piece sleeves (top and bottom halves) are snug on his arms.Levi Gregory Metcalf was born Oct. 31 [or Nov. 1,] 1831 in Cattaraugus County, New York in the Allegany Mountains. He lived in Paris, Edgar County, Illinois before joining the Church of Jesus Christ LDS and forging west.
source: Donor, ElizabethCrandall from Springville, Carma's student of historic clothing at BYU. Levi G. Metcalf was Elizabeth's ancestor. Free use.

caption: John Taylor wearscurls, andan overcoat with a quilted lining, ca. 1850.
description: John Taylor wears fine clothing in his middle life. Over his black coat and white silk vest is a beautiful tanovercoat with a quilted lining of sage silk. The many buttons with lapel holes up the entire length of both sides was a standard tailor's device. His cuffs and collar are matching velvet, and two ball-head studsclose a white linen shirt in front. His tie is common blacksilkin a bow knot. From England, Taylor immigrated to Toronto, Canada, where he married highly educated Leonora Cannon, fromthe Isle of Man.  They soon joined the Church of Jesus Christ LDS growing community in that city. Their labors heightened the spiritual levels of the group. Eventually,Taylor became the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ LDS.
source: Taylor was painted during a mission to France by the talented Utah artist, Lorus Pratt. From Biographical Encyclopedia,(Salt Lake City, 1901, vol. 1). Reprinted on demand byAmazon Digital Services LLC since 2012.Color image found on the Internet at -- https://www.lds.org/ensign/1971/08/the-government-of-god?lang=eng

caption: Reynolds Cahoon, a wealthy merchant with fine clothes, ca. 1850.
description: Reynolds Cahoon (1790 –1861) wears a turned-down shirt collar with rounded points, not heavily starched. He has a black or dark silk tie, probably from a long strip of silk. The edges of the coat's collar and lapels have a silk tape binding.His waistcoat is buttoned high with coveredbuttons. The white hair around Reynold's bald area is earlobe-length with a slight wave. He has long sideburns. Cahoon was an early leader in the Church of Jesus Christ LDS in Kirtland, Ohio, a Member of the Kirtland temple committee, and a major shopkeeper in the early 1830s. His scrolled handwriting in long ledgers has been preserved. Carma has read in those ledgers what a great many and variety of fabrics and trims he sold to both Church of Jesus Christ LDS and non-LDSin Ohio. He migrated tothe West with the major body of the Saints.
source: Image from internet: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reynolds_Cahoon

caption: Joseph F. Smith, the son of Hyrum, was called on a Church mission to Hawaii at age 15. Ca. 1858.
description: Thoughmaturing, Joseph wasnot yet a man. He wears a bunchy black tie and a folded down white collar.A small pin decorates the front of his shirt. The ring on his finger belonged to his father, and his suit --from whatever source--is too wide for him; the lapels reach almost to his shoulders. The dark vest is double-breasted. His hair appears to have been chopped off in the most economical way.       After his father was assassinated, Joseph F. walked to Utah with his mother and little sister.  President Brigham Young decided to send Joseph F. on a mission (without purse or scrip), announcing his calling in General Conference. Glad to go, but all alone, Joseph worked in San Francisco to earn passage.  During his first year in the Islands,he didn't know the language and nearly starved, but was taken in by a big, kind, "Hawaiian Mama" who nursedhim to health.After learning Hawaiian and serving successfully for 4 years, Joseph simply made his return, grown into a man, with a strong testimony and a powerful drive to be well educated. In 1866 he became an apostle. In 1890 he was called assixth President and Prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
source: Joseph. F. Smith at 15 in Hawaii, 1858, Church of Jesus Christ LDS Archives.   Also online at -- www.latterdaylight.com/the-latter-day-light-blog/2018/8/13/true-blue-mormon

caption: Huge, plaid silk tie on Sam Houston, pioneer roust-about and colonizer of Texas. Ca. 1850s.
description: A national fad for men’s ties featured an extra-large, blunt-ended, horizontal square knot.Note also Sam’s unusual vest of a fancy print, which boasts both a collar and a scalloped layer over his chest.  Houston seems to have enjoyed bold, unusual vests.
source: Daguerreotype portrait, International Museum of Photography, Rochester, New York.

caption: Another Sam Houston silk tie has an asymmetrical bow
description: This horizontal bow came into fashion in the 1850s and is seen on a daguerreotype portrait of Sam Houston,
source: From a display in the State Historical Society of Wisconsin (WHi[X3]35720). Drawn by Carma.  Free use.

caption: John Taylor’s portrait an in 1850s hair and clothing.
description: Taylor’s blondish, curling hair is parted on the side and combed over.  His large, blue eyes, deeply set into his clean-shaven face, indicated his loving manner. A tie of figured silk is done in a square knotover a shirt front with two studs. The very light blue of his eyes appearsas white, making him look astonished.John Taylor, of Milnthorpe, England, immigrated first into Toronto, Canada, and then to America, when he and his wife, Leonora, joined the Church of Jesus Christ LDS  in Toronto.  He became an apostle, and then Church Prophet and President in 1880. Taylor was with Joseph Smith when that prophet was assassinated in Carthage, Illinois, and was, himself, seriously wounded by the mob. He survived with Willard Richards' help.
source: Internet: www.lds.org/manual/teachings-john-taylor/historical-summary?lang=eng   and other internet locations.

caption: LDS Apostle and missionary, Parley P. Pratt, dresses neatly on a middle-class budget, ca.1850s.
description: A narrow band of collar is turned down over the wrapped, scarf-style cravat, which is square knotted. With the ends held in place by anornamented stickpin, it is tucked into a medium-high, small-buttoned vest with a collar. His coat has a simple slash lapel with high buttonholes on each side, which are probably never buttoned. Though Parley is balding, he still has a considerable puff of hair on top, and rather short, curled hair around and behind his ears.  Sideburns are narrow, and only as long as his earlobes.Pratt married Thankful Halsey in 1827, and thereafter traveled the world on LDS missions, occasionally able to take his wife with him. He had a huge influence in the Eastern US, Canada,and England as a theologian. With a poetic bent, he wrote words for several hymns; and more pamphlets than any other Church member to explain Church of Jesus Christ LDS beliefs. His autobiography is still widely read and appreciated for his skilled writing and many adventures. It covers his vast missionary work from Chile in South America to the northern hemisphere and in the British Isles.
source: Widely seen and reported on the internet.

caption: A pre-structured cravat with a front knot we cannot discernislikely buttoned together in back for quick convenience. Ca. 1850s.
description: William Crisp Wilding, a lifetime shoemaker from England, wearshisbest clothing for going to church.  Alsoformal occasions such as funerals or weddings. Only a bit of his standing white collar is seen above it. If he wears a mustache, the hair is too light to clearly distinguish.  His hair is light and cut to ear length.Quality clothing was uncommon in the Staffordshire Pottery District of the five towns around Stoke On Trent. William contributed money and effort to the Church after his and his daughter's baptisms. As a widower, he loved doing missionary work in the area around Stoke on Trent in England. His Church-member daughter, Eliza, married Osmond Broad Shaw. Theyleft Britain after three years to join the Saints in Zion. In America,Eliza's husband drove a wagon full of furniture and precious bolts of English fabrics for her work as a "stay-maker." Eliza walked all the way across the plains and wore out 4 pairs of her father's fine shoes made for her trousseau. When William was 90 years old, his son-in-law, Osmond Broad Shaw, came back to England for an 18monthChurch mission, and brought back William to America with him, to live in Salt Lake City.  There Williamlived a very active life of walking scores of milesover the early roadsof Utah and died at age 101 ½fromfalling off a roof he was repairing.
source: Carma's great-grandfather, froma family history withthis photo. Free use.

caption: Young Orson Pratt’s clothing is immaculately tailored. Ca. 1851.
description: Orson's coat has fairly wide lapels, with a vestbeneath with shiny satin lapels.Around his stiffened stand-up collar is a very long, black,silk bias-cut scarf. It is fashionably wrapped across the front, crossed in the back,and then brought forward again to fall in artful disarray before tying in a knot and tucking the ends below the vest's neckline. The cravat appears to have sewn-on ornamentation. Oliver is carefully shaved, American style, and has perfectly smooth hair with long, closely clipped sideburns and slight curls above his ears.
source: This Orson Pratt detail is cropped from a family painting done by a very skillful, unknown watercolorist in England, 1851. The original watercolor of his whole family together was photographed many years ago by Carma in the Office of the General Director of the Salt Lake City DUP.  This detail found on the internet at: https://www.josephsmithpapers.org/person/orson-pratt

caption: Lorenzo Snow in his first known portrait, an engraving, at about age 39, ca. 1853.
description: Snow wears lengthy natural curls on the top and sides of his head. A continental cropped beard is around his jawline connecting to his sideburns. Over an attractive, horizontal tie, his collar is turned down. Snow always wore the finest in tailoring. The details of the coat and vest are disguised by themoiré effect of scanning this image.Originating in a highly educated family in Mantua, Ohio, he was a brother of Eliza R. Snow, the Church of Jesus Christ LDS Poetess. He became an apostle in 1849, and the Prophet and President of the LDS in 1898. He felt too old and weak for the calling, but the Lord assured him in a remarkable vision in the Salt Lake City Temple, that he could do the work for a short time. Greatly loved for his gentle faithfulness, he led the widely spreading church for three years until his death in 1901. A protestant minister who met him in his last years said the elderly Snow had the “holiest face I ever saw.”
source: This engraving by Frederick Piercy is in the Church of Jesus Christ LDS Archives and online.

caption: Orson Hyde in a daguerreotype of 1853 wears a fancy vest.
description: This member of the twelve apostles of President Joseph Smith was unusual in affording a very handsome silk fabric for his vest. His narrow collar is folded down over a small, plain tie in a squareknot.  (The moiré lines in the tie and coat fabric are a result of scanning an image thatis not printed with dots. The fabrics were actually solid colors.)Note that he still adopts the earlier fashion of brushing forward his side hair, which was more popular from 1800 to 1830. Elder Hyde served many exciting and important missions in two hemispheres.
source: Picture courtesy of Virginia Jeanette Wooley Quealy. Free use. Use

caption: Dan Jones in an enlargement of a small sketch from a group picture ca. 1855.
description: Dan Jones from Wales wears a very narrow, wrap-around, knotted tie,and short muttonchop whiskers. We see here a high-buttoned vest with a small notched collar. His tie is a narrow piece of hemmed silk, knotted and tucked into the vest. His sideburns continue into short-cropped muttonchops, but he wears no beard. He had little money for clothing, so he wore many things people gave him during his numerous Church missions back to his homeland.Jones was instrumentalin the conversions of 300 Welch men and women.
source: Enhanced for clarity by Carma, his bust drawing was taken from a blurry group photograph.  Carma enlarged it by Photoshop, then repaired his damaged eyes fromthe original image. Free use.

caption: Joseph Smith III, son of Joseph Smith Jr., wears a fine, satin striped vest and straw hat, ca. late 1850s.
description: This detail of Joseph Smith 3rd's professional photograph shows him with his mustache and lower-chin beard, withhair below his earlobes.  An intricately-knotted, silk cravatis worn beneath his turned-down collar. His silk vest with a narrow shawl collar is woven in satin cross-stripes and hasseven buttons --an expensive number. He carries a dark straw hat the color of maple syrup for hot summers in Missouri, and his black coat has regular notched lapels. Smith grew to be a tall man like his forebears. Joseph had dark eyes and featureslike his mother, Emma Hale Smith. He became the president of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ LDS, now called the Community of Christ.
source: Courtesy of Community of Christ Archives.  Also online at – www.pbs.org/mormons/peopleevents/p_smith.html

caption: 1850s Heavy silk vest with blue-black stripes woven in.
description: This double-breasted vest is exhibited somewhat folded.  Unusually, it has a broad, false collar sewn as part of the structure, standing upward.  It is not a real collar folded over.  Very small silk-covered buttons hold it closed. It appearsto have a conventional white linen back that may be somewhat worn out at the neckline. The vest must have been made on an early sewing machine with top-stitching, rather than being made by hand stitches, so it was probably brought to Utah from the East Coast where sewing machines were first sold.
source: Donor, Laura Angell Gregory King, Salt Lake City DUP Museum, # 3479. Worn by Albert Gregory in the 1850s in Utah.

caption: Left - A very high cravat buttons on behind the neck. Ca. 1850-on
description: This neckwear of black, delustered, silk satin has internal white stiffening fabric to hold the cravat erect. Two buttons at the center back conveniently fasten it closed. A second, narrower tie with a very flat bow is added onto thelower edge.
source: Exhibit 1984 at Rochester Historical Society, New York. Donation in good condition from the Silas O. Smith family. Photo by Carma from an exhibit catalog. Free use.

caption: Right –A silver cufflink
source: Illustrated by Carma from  MCHA.has internal white stiffening fabric to hold the cravat erect.

caption: Enlarged cameo studs for man's shirt front, mid-1800s.
description: These ornate studsare worn onmen's dressy shirt fronts, enlarged 400% for clarity. Each stud would have been about ½ inch tall. They are Wedgewood designs of blue and white, or white on darker Jasperware, all mounted on gold.The little portraits are tiny paintings mounted on the gold stud front. A dress shirt has buttonholes on both right and left sides, and the plain sideof the stud goes through both buttonholes, leaving onlythe decorated side visible on the front of the shirt.On top left,see the profile of a plain shirt stud showing how it is used to connect the two buttonholes, ratherlike 2 buttons attached by a stem.  On the lower left,we faintlysee the brassyback of one Wedgewood stud.  The dense shadows in the display case limit clear visibility.
source: from English Manchester Collection of Costumes. Photo by Carma, Free use.

caption: Man's long underdrawers, 1850s to 1870s,
description: Around the waist is a finely quilted band thatbecomes deeper in the center front, where three buttons close the band. The placket opening must have an extension of extra fabric inside, though we see no buttons for that illustrated. The center seam was left open. There would be a rear button flap, as well, for toilet convenience. At the leg-hems are fabric straps to go under the feet to keep the underwear from riding up beneath trousers. These drawers could be made of linen/cotton, but more likely merino wool knit for greater warmth. Since trousers tended to be snug, it is assumed that drawers were snug as well, to keep from showing wrinkles through outer trousers -a good reason for knitted underdrawers.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Also online. Free use.

caption: Men’s knee-length underdrawers could be worn with breeches or trousers. Front and back views, all 1800s.
description: As with the long underdrawers above, these have a wide waistband, and are open below it in front.  Note that the backview has more fabric to ease sitting, and adjustable drawstrings to accommodate waist size. These knee-length underdrawers tie below the knee and would have been cooler to wear in summer.(Side note: women wore corsets to narrow their waistlines and hold their stomachs in.  This author wonders if the wide waistbands helped perform the same duty for men. It is true that corsets did exist for men to achieve the “wasp waist” popular earlier in the century --as shown on this website in “Men 1830s. But bymid-century, hardly anyone wore breeches, except for the British on formal occasions, and men’s corsets were mostly abandoned.)
source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/80014266?img=0Public domain. Free use.

caption: Wedding suspender, one of a pair embroidered on heavy cotton cloth by the bride-to-be. Ca.1850-70.
description: Suspenders needed stiff backing and leather ends for buttoning onto trousers. A bride's gift to her husband was her embroidered flowers and leaves on a white fabric, made into a real pair of separate suspenders. This kind of gift became traditional among the middle and upper-class brides who had time forembroidering. Suspenders were also called galluses.
source: drawn by Carma from many different clothing sources in books and clothing collections. FREE USE.

caption: British or American store clerk of mid-1800s with eyeglasses propped on his forehead (detail).
description: Though spectacles had been in use for over a century, this clerk only needs them to read and write records, and props them on his forehead when serving a customer. His shirt and tie are disheveled, many medium-sized buttons close his high, too-tight vest, and a coat has large buttons down the front.  (These buttons are an ovaltrademark of the particular author-artist in his drawing. The unusual oval shape is used for every button in all his illustrations. In reality, the buttons would be round.)His coat elbows are patched from much wear.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, in care of Department of Textiles. 1977).

caption: Men’s wig on George A.Smithafter he had lost most of his hair.2 images, ca. 1850-1870
description: George A. Smith, a Church apostle and the nephew of Joseph Smith Jr. was called by Brigham Young to preach to the Saints colonizing Southern Utah.In the upper image, elegantly dressed, George has an under-chin beard of white curls that do not match his wig, which mismatch did not distress himat all.  In the lower image, the wig has undergone long, hard wear and looks frazzled.During later life,While wearing this wig, he was known to become so overheated, he would pull off the wig, mop his dripping brow, then plop it back in place and continue preaching. Great laughter arose from his audiences who loved him for his faith and unabashed humor.Note his vest in the lower image. Double-breasted, it is buttoned very highwith lapels stickingforward,as was often seen in the 70s. His ties in both images do not seem to be tied with much care. Smithwas given an Indian name meaning "man who comes apart," The Indians treated him with awe as they watched him remove glasses, teeth, wig, cane –and even a wooden leg! He always spoke at great length, one day for three and ahalf hours! On another occasion when he suffered from a cold, he spoke too long and then required a long very quiet rest.
source: Zora Smith Jarvis, George A. Smith Family, Ancestry, Biography and Family(Provo, UT, Brigham Young University Press, 1962). Images from Jarvis book and online.

caption: William McKee Fausett & wife Ruth in Provo, UT. Ca. 1850s.
description: This long-term Bishop of the Provo, Utah Ward has a full white beard that makes him look older than his 50 years. His coat has rounded lower corners and sleeves of normal width. His vest buttons up high on his chest. Slightly lighter wool trousers are loose. Wearing a felt hat with a rounded crown, he also holds a useful cane. These were his best clothes during the colonizing years in Utah. His 2 nd wife is Ruth Bailey (Logan) Cloward, formerly widowed. She wears a flat straw hat with stand-up trimmings. The center front of her dark dress has buttons to below her waist with a jacket over the top and a double chain necklace. Her petticoats are moderate during the settling of Utah in the 1850s--Provo being far from a fashion center.
source: Photo online atwww.findagrave.com/memorial/12550402/william-mckeefausett

caption: Henry Maiben, talented actor and comedian in the old Salt Lake Theater and wife Flora Louise Maddison, Ca. 1850s to 1880s.
description: Henry wears fashionable clothing representing a role for the late 1830s with a horizontal satin tie, a padded-up collar in back, and gathers at the top of his sleeves. The vest is of figured satin. His curly hair is cut to the ear lobes. An actor in many kinds of roles in the Salt Lake Theater, Maiben was much applauded by lovers of drama and comedy. Like others in the early theater, he also built sets, painted scenery, and helped in all parts of the background production. Occasionally, his wife, the beautiful Flora Louise Maddison, took parts on stage as well, even while producing twelve children. Flora, a convert who had been raised with servants of the British royal family, was a woman of much refinement and good education. She was well-received as a sometimes-actress. She wears pearl earrings and necklace in an early portrait.
source: Courtesy of descendants: Lorie Nicholes Davis and James W. Nicholes. Free use.

caption: A Family group wears better clothing in ambrotype, 1852.
description: Though all seem weary of this long photo-sitting, they display very fine middle-class clothing. Mother’s ensemble includes an ornate lace collar and large oval broach. Sleeves of a different fabric show under a darker overblouse with ribbons. We see her gold watch, two gold finger rings, and bright earrings. Her hair has been swept back and up from a center part in stand-out loops above her ears. She may have deliberate “rats” beneath to hold that shape, though the rest of her hair hangs down straight in back. One outstanding feature of this family image is that both children wear large, shiny belt buckles. The little boy’s hair is swept up into a large curl on top, and his ornate jacket has dark buttons and trim that let his white shirt sleeve show through from elbow to wrist. His shirt has ruffles down the front. The little girl has lacy ruffles on her bodice-front and sleeves and a velvet skirt. Father’s clothing is unremarkable, but his hair is puffed out at ear-length, and his beard and mustache are thick and dark.
source: Charleston, South Carolina Museum, MK 11 ambrotype, Seen in Joan L Severa, Dressed for the Photographer: Ordinary Americans and Fashion, 1840-1900, (Kent, Ohio, Kent State University Press, 2005)

caption: American family group in common clothing, ca. 1859.
description: An ambrotype shows the boy in center in an unusual bias-cut shirt with a white collar and a wide bow tie. His sister on left has a dotted dress and ankle-high shoes. Father is bald on top with a “comb-over” and flipped-up hair over his ears, a common style. He has very light eyebrows, and a chinline beard touches his slightly folded-over collar and barrel-knotted tie. The coat and vest are medium-toned fabric, with lighter trousers. The mother has very large stripes running horizontally across her plaid dress, with very full sleeves gathered in at the wrists above fingerless gloves. She has a pretty linen collar with rows of crocheting on the outside edge. Her hair has typical side sections combed down and draped back from a center part into poofs over the ears and gathered into a bun behind.
source: Ambrotype by Joseph Covais (deceased) in Joan L Severa, Dressed for the Photographer: Ordinary Americans and Fashion, 1840-1900, (Kent, Ohio, Kent State University Press, 2005)

caption: Tinted ambrotype of a family with four children. Ca. 1850s.
description: Sepia-colored to begin with as an ambrotype, this image is also is handtinted, showing two of the boys in red shirts. The boys' special buckled belts were fashionable in the 1850s. All three boys have white collars and knotted neckerchiefs with their long trousers. Some of the stockings seem gray- - probably accurate. The baby is in a warm, long-sleeved dress under a light blanket. Mother has a lavender-gray print dress of very full skirt, possibly of wool, with a white collar and broach. The father has a turned-down collar for comfort, a further indication of the date. His dark vest buttons up very high under his medium-dark coat.
source: Courtesy W. Michael Nielsen, whose ancestors here are un-named.

caption: 1850s Family of Julius and Fanny Brooks, the first Jews in Salt Lake City.
description: The remarkable, German Brooks (Bruchs) were the first Jews to settle in Salt Lake City, and there enjoyed great financial success. Mother Fanny has a trendy scrolling of cord on her long-sleeved Garibaldi bodice of mid-toned fabric. Wide lace frills extend from her wrists. Dark buttons close the front bodice below a lace piece crossed at the neckline. Her hair has a wide black velvet ribbon bow on top, perhaps attached to some type of clip or snood. Father Julius wears checked trousers with a dark coat, figured all over. His boots have square toes. A mustache and clipped chin beard expose his collar and bow tie. His hair is cut short. The toddler boy on his lap sits in a dress with a frill around the yoke and a high neck. His ankle-high shoes are laced and tied. Their daughter wears a silk dress with a bodice draping up to bows on the shoulders and ruffles descending from the bows. Sleeves are short and straight. Her hair is pulled back with a headband. A standing brother has a jacket of medium wool with black tape bordering all edges. We see a bit of a white shirt collar and cuff. His trousers are ample length, and his hair has a neat side parting.
source: This image was found and photographed by Carma in the 1950s at a forgotten California university library, and is in the public domain. A brief but interesting bio is at https://ilovehistory.utah.gov/people/difference/brooks.html

caption: An illustrated certificate for a personal event called a “Fractur,” in German, ca. 1852.
description: This is an American-made, illustrated certificate for a personal event. In German it is called a “Fractur,” and these types of certificates were common among GermanAmericans. Standing on a green lawn is a young father in a black, cutaway tailcoat with royal blue trousers and holding a bouquet. The new young mother wears a red over-blouse with bell-shaped sleeves, much lace and trimming, and a black apron. The belled, cream-colored dress beneath is dotted with tiny roses. Both parents have black hair and finger-sized feet (popular in folk art to signify refinement). This certificate is for a German-American baby’s birth and sprinkling baptism, 1852.
source: Potter Township, Center City, Pennsylvania, American Radiance: The Ralph Essmerian Gift to the American Folk Art Museum (in association with Harry N. Abrams, Inc. 100 Fifth Ave. New York, New York, 10011. Public Domain.

caption: Wedding pictures of Dr. Ezra Williams and Electa Barney Williams, 1857.
description: In 1857, blond Ezra wore a beard and a white, stiff-starched collar. His tie was either a dark color or black. A small stud fastens the front of his shirt. Smaller coat lapels are very high buttoned in the latest British fashion. Electa may have naturally curly hair. One large ringlet falls onto her shoulder. (This ringlet may be her own hair or an attached hairpiece.) A lacy neckerchief with scalloped ends is fastened by a broach. Note the large, decorative stitches flaring out from the neckline of her dress. Around her neck is also a necklace of beads. Her earrings are large metal droplets with a jewel in the center and below.
source: Both on the Internet by individual name. Free use.

caption: Heber C. Kimball, wife Christeen Golden Kimball, and their first daughter, Cornelia, 1853.
description: Heber, an apostle of the early Church of Jesus Christ LDS, wears a medium-dark suit with matching trousers and coat, an emerging fashion called “the English mode.” Earlier, trousers were a lighter tone than the coat. Buttonholes extend up the flat lapel but are never fastened. A double-breasted satin vest has lapels and tiny cloth buttons. His tie of figured silk is in a horizontal square knot, with a high collar folded down over it. In mid-life, Heber’s hair was dark but rapidly balding. His sideburns are longer, as was the fashion. Christeen wears a shirred bodice that gathers to the center front above her large skirt of striped fabric. Her raised bust line shows she is obviously wearing a corset, as was usual with women of social status. She has a white insert at the neckline and a gold chain. Lacy engageants are narrow from the elbow to the wrist beneath bell sleeves. Her long hair is parted in the center with braids wrapped back and forth across the crown of her head. Little Cornelia has a simple dress with pleats across the bodice in enfant style. Her naturally curly hair is parted in the center. This little daughter died at four years of age.
source: Salt Lake City, DUP. Information from Kate B. Carter 1967.

caption: Reverend Charles Grandison Finney and wife Elizabeth Atkinson Finney, ca. 1850.
description: This devout and renowned Christian couple was greatly influential in preaching Christ to many others less devout. He was a Presbyterian called The Great Revivalist. They are both wearing ministerial black with white collars. His tie is white and clerical, indistinguishable from his collar. His vest has a very high-buttoned collar. Elizabeth’s dress is gathered in from shoulder to center waistline. Her sleeves are narrow, and she holds a folded parasol. Deep, un-pressed pleats fill out her large skirt. Her modest day cap is flat across the top, with only slight gathering and sheer ribbons at the sides. Small clusters of curls peep out over her cheeks.
source: A daguerreotype of 1850s seen on the internet. Other images in Nathan O, Hatch, The Democratization of American Christianity, (New Haven, Connecticut, Yale University Press; Reprint edition, 1991).

caption: Orson & Sarah Pratt family in England. Ca. 1851.
description: Orson is seen here in his best English wool suit and black silk-satin vest. He has black square-toed boots. His wife Sarah is dressed in a silk figured dress. A front panel has rose silk appliques on black. Many buttons down the bodice are topped by a green ribbon bow and a broach. She wears a white collar and has short engageants under her bell sleeves. Her day cap has wide lace ruffles hanging from the front, a casual fashion of the time. Their oldest son standing by his mother is dressed as a man because he is fourteen.  A little son in a blue dress stands beside his father in pantalets and Mary Jane shoes. The older sister wears a blue silk dress with a green sash, a much-loved color combination. The red-haired baby has pale blue ribbons on her white batiste dress. Four months from the time of this painting, the baby girl died. Carved, background paneling is a figment of the artist's imagination to add dignity to the sitters. The Pratts were not as wealthy as the painting seems to indicate but they had very fine taste and education.
source: Photo by Carma of the small watercolor painting by an unknown artist in the office of the President of the Salt Lake City DUP Museum, taken in 2000. Free use.

caption: Boott Cotton Mills in Lowel, Massachusetts, 1852.
description: Young people and even children and worked in American mills amid dangerous conditions and for long hours. But outside of most mills were some small, park-like areas to make lunch half-hours a little nicer. The adults seen here are probably the owners of the mills with their friends, for we see fine clothing of large skirts and shawls in multi-colors and men in top hats. Women’s bonnets are color-coordinated with their clothing, and are still deep brimmed, as they were in the previous decade. The men wear light-colored trousers with darker coats, which was the fashion.
source: Postcard in color showing a large scene of Boot Cotton Mills in Lowel, Massachusetts, Hand-colored wood engraving from Gleason's Pictorial, Drawing Room Companion. Published in Boston, 1852. Free use. use.

caption: TYPICAL 1850s dresses ranged from gowns more moderate than these to very much fuller and more ornate.
description: Dresses for daytime (right) had full skirts with crinoline hoops and tightly corsetted waists. They were quite modest, covering to the neck and wrists, but with fabric quality, sewing, and décor according to what the wearer could afford. Shawls and headpieces were common indoors, and bonnets were absolutely required for outdoor wear. Evening wear was low-necked or off-shoulder, with short, snug sleeves. Many layers of skirts, overskirts, or flounces were admired. The more decoration one could afford, the better to show wealth. Hairpieces of curls, flowers, feathers, and ribbons were popular. These styles were worn as much as possible by all classes of women. Lower-classes bought clothing 2nd or 3rd hand clothing from stores or street carts.
source: Hundreds of examples for every occasion are online at 1850s women's dresses.

caption: Dresses and hairstyles of four fashionable women. 1850s.
description: All women wear white collars of lace or inset fabric, often with a broach, topping silk dresses. All sleeves are “pagoda” flares with various edge decorations and white engageants beneath. All are probably of rich colors. Skirts are very full. Waistlines are either a soft center point or a “jacket-bottom” W-shaped style, which may mean they are two-piece dresses. The woman on right has a dotted silk dress with a shawl of silk with velvet trim. Hairstyles all begin with a center part but are poofed out elaborately on the sides. Two younger girls wear head-bands. Left lady has a dainty band of lace and diagonal sausage curls on the sides, while woman on right has a fancy knot of hair in back over satin-smooth side poofs. All these hairstyles would have required the service of maids or dressers and might have support structures beneath the hair poofs. Right and left women wear leather gloves.
source: From a daguerreotype in the George Eastman House Collection.

caption: Two-piece dress of red and green plaid wool, ca. 1840s and 50s.
description: This red plaid wool bodice is separate from the skirt. Its waistline is cut to form a pleasant rounded V at the center. It probably had brass hooks or inexpensive buttons up the back since it is simple enough to typify someone who was not wealthy. The separate skirt has un-pressed pleats facing toward the center front and center back. It would have been worn over several petticoats and possibly a crinoline hoop. The sleeves are fitted smoothly at the slightly-dropped shoulder but are moderately gathered at the narrow cuffs. The high round neckline has a frayed edging but was probably worn with a collar of plain fabric or lace over the top. This dress was not in a public display, therefore was not shown with the full petticoats or crinoline that would have greatly flared out the skirt.
source: Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn, New York. Photo by Carma, Free use.

caption: A wool plaid dress entirely made by a pioneer husband for his wife - sheered, dyed, woven, and sewn, ca. 1850s.
description: A highly dedicated husband created a wool plaid dress from sheep to shape for his wife. He clipped the wool from his sheep, cleaned the wool: washed, carded, dyed raw wool in bundles with red, black, and blue colors. Then he spun the wool rolags (carded wool hanks) into threads for the loom, took extra effort to string the loom, and wove the plaid yardage. The fabric was carefully steam pressed to help smooth and shrink the fabric before cutting it The husband then cut out the dress pieces and hand sewed all parts of the bodice and lining together. Tiny buttons were applied to ribbon designs down the double-tucked bodice front. These were very expensive brass buttons made in the design of a slightly flattened, hollow, cone shape with a shank for sewing on.
source: A mannequin years ago was just being prepared for display in the Salt Lake City DUP Museum. The skirt, as you can see, has only been pinned onto the bodice at this point. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Rebecca Burlend in a beautiful wool dress having full sleeves and double caplets below the shoulders. 1850s.
description: In this excellent depiction of a wool dress, Rebecca has comfortably full sleeves, and 1850s caplet sleeves. Stripes of black silk braid line the caplets and edge of her fold-back cuffs. The front bodice opens from neck to waist in mid-century style with tiny buttons and a necessary placket about 8 inches below the waist. Deep pleats on each side of the front buttons give a shawl-like effect and disguise her aging, flat figure. She seems comfortabe not wearing a corset but still looking her best. It appears that the gathering of the skirt is made with cartridge pleating, with probably more fullness in folds of the center back. Her small day cap has cheeky ruffles and a checkered ribbon to tie under the chin. Her hands are covered with necessary gloves which disguise many years of hard work colonizing wilderness land. We see no other jewelry on her. The hem of her dress may have silk tape on the hemline also. Rebecca Burlend - (1793–1872) wrote A True Picture of Emigration with her husband.
source: Photo on the internet at: https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=AmzuGPSvAsfSYCTv7LzggCKbvZx4?p=Rebecca+Burlend&toggle=1&cop=mss&ei=UTF-8&fr=yfp-t-901-1

caption: Woman's printed, wool challis gown of 1850s, with a broad hat.
description: Woman's blue-lavender, wool challis gown is printed with pink designs and has black velvet covered bodice buttons. The bell sleeves have more velvet buttons at dropped sleeve tops and a band of velvet applied at the bottom edge. We cannot see engageants, but a woman covered her lower arms during the daytime. A black velvet binding of emphasizes the hem. A very broad straw hat is an elegant pewter color with a large white flower and leaves on the hatband. Though hats of the 1850s and 60s tended to grow smaller as skirts grew wider, a woman exposed to sunlight would wear a broad-brimmed hat to protect her complexion. The model carries fresh magenta flowers in a fashion show. Her hair would most certainly NOT be worn down as shown. It would be center-parted and drawn back into a bun, twist or chignon, perhaps with side ringlets. At night hair was braided to keep it in order. Only little girls wore their hair down. It was a mark of womanhood to “put up your hair,” all the way into the 20th century. See authentic hairstyles in the HAIR AND BONNETsection below.
source: An unknown donor sent the dress to Carma. After use in fashion shows, it was donated to the BYU College of Fine Arts Historical Clothing Collection, as was ALL of Carma’s other historic clothing. Modeled by April Engles. Photo by United Photo Studio (long gone). Free use.

caption: Day dress has fabric of unusual vertical stripes and a second flounce. Ca. 1850s.
description: This mannequin’s skirt has two long flounces, the upper one edged by a shiny ribbon which is also printed to add more design! Bell-shaped sleeves, narrow on the upper arm, display batiste engageants beneath. The mannequin wears a sheer broderie Anglaise collar extending four inches around the high neck and closed with a horizontal, oblong broach. She has sheer, black fingerless gloves It is likely that there are hooks beneath the bodice placket. The bodice may be separate from the waistband of the skirt. The wig is not in a hairstyle contemporary with the dress (see hairstyles section below).
source: Historic Cherry Hill, Albany, NY. Photo May have come from a book, but Carma doesn’t know which. She will gladly give full credit for use of their photos as they desire, or will remove this image from her site.

caption: Irish silk dress with blonde lace from the British film, 'Little Dorrit,’ of ca. 1840s-50s.
description: In Nauvoo, Salt Lake City, and other large cities, wealthy people brought lovely clothing from Britain or across the plains to be used after their settlement. This wide-necked taffeta dress was for a young marriageable woman. It has elbow-length, straight sleeves with a short, full puff section around the arm above the elbow. The center front bodice is tightly shirred horizontally down to a low center point. The flanges around the shoulders meet in a front V-shape. The back bodice has covered hooks to close the dress. Most likely this is a two-piece ball gown. Petticoats make it as wide as is danceable. She holds a paper or silk Japanese fan. Added hair-piece ringlets on the sides of her face are held with flowery, horizontal combs or half-wreath. She wears sheer, fingerless gloves, and a short necklace.
source: Worn by Amelda Brown in the British film, 'Little Dorrit. Photo by permission of Lord Snowdon. Free use.

caption: 1851 Fringe and tassels on women's gown.
description: In the mid-1800s, and for the next 50 years, many quality dresses in Britain, Europe, and America, in 1 piece and 2 piece gowns for daytime or for balls, began to use heavier trims of fringes and tassels. It is a special golden brocade silk gown with golden silk fringe on the lower edges of double bell-shaped sleeves and on the border of a capelet which meets in the front, its horizontal border of fringe falling over the bodice and tops of the sleeves. This dress only uses fringe for trimming, which calls attention to the heavy and beautiful brocade fabric, all within a limited color range for impact. It is notable that the Utah Governor's mansion was restored to this period of 1850s to 1870s, the pioneer years, with much furniture and drapery employing heavy fringes, tassels, and heavier fabrics of the era.
source: This local of this photo is forgotten, possibly from the Crystal Palace International Exposition of 1851. The only attribution known is “K. J. Harris.” Correct information and attribution is sought and welcomed.

caption: 1840s-50s Wedding gown cream figured silk of 1840,
description: Flounces at the wide neck and elbow-length sleeves have fancy-cut (not hemmed) edges. When they became frayed, the edges would be re-cut by extra-sharp embroidery scissors. Below the neck flounce, a pleated drape across the bodice is called a "corsage," and is held in center-front by a loop or a fancy broach.
