Below a deeply pointed bodice waistline, the skirt is also pleated. The bride wears fingerless lace mitts and carries an ivory fan. Her hair is center-parted and swooped down over her ears and up into a nest of curls secured by an ornate comb. Dangling earrings might be made of any jewel or pearl.
source: drawn by Carma after a gown in the Cincinnati Museum of Art, Cincinnati, Ohio. Free use.

caption: Wedding dress bodice made of English lawn with a woven, all-white plaid design. Textile from 1850.
description: This fabric was a gift to his sweetheart, brought home from a mill center in England to Fairview, Utah, to make his bride a special wedding dress. Many years later, when her daughter was married, she took part of the enormous skirt fabric and made these wide flared sleeves to change the original narrow style of the first sleeves. The bodice is fully lined because the fabric is translucent. Top-stitching holds the neckline and arms-eyes in place. The top of the sleeve is a flat semi-circle above the gathering of the lower portion. The skirt was large enough to go over many petticoats. The center bodice, with princess lines, is gathered at the bottom into a belt-like insertion. If the daughter’s dress was made to look antique in style, there may have been engageants worn under these wide sleeves,
source: Fairview, Utah Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: 1850s White wedding dress of the wealthy in white silk and lace, with shoulder flounce,
description: White wedding dresses became popular after Queen Victoria was married in white. The bride’s bodice has a scalloped lace collar of very fine crochet. Just showing above the collar is a sheer, embroidered, wide-necked chemise. Flowers were often pinned to the center front of the bride's neckline -- artificial sweet peas cascade almost to her waist. The very deep, narrow, V-shaped, waist point is likely held in place with a busk. Unpressed pleats flare her white silk skirt under more lace. The sleeves are unseen beneath the generous shoulder flounces, though their delicate lace shows below. She is wearing round, pearl earrings, and only a simple bracelet as she holds fresh flowers in her gloveless hands. The bride’s glossy hair is center-parted, then rolled back into two full puffs above her ears. Her back hair would be an elegant twist. Less wealthy brides wore gowns of colors and prints that could be worn as “best dresses” after the wedding.
source: Beaumont Newhall, The Daguerreotype in America, (Mineola, New York, Dover Publications, 3 Revised edition, June 1, 1976).

caption: Blue satin Gown with changed bodices for day & evening, 1850s.
description: A blue satin evening gown has a separate bodice with a shirred point at the waist and a peplum ruffle to overlap her skirt (pix at right) For daywear, her jacket has a wide ruffle lining the deep V-neck. Both peplum and bell sleeve-ends have fancy edging. This seems excessive décor on gleaming satin. A sheer white length extends beyond the jacket sleeves. A sheer blue bonnet for daytime has a short brim to show her side ringlets and a sheer bavolet ruffle covering her back neck. For a ball, she would remove the jacket and hat, and wear hair ornaments.
source: Photos by Carma at Woodside Mansion, open to the public in Rochester by the Historical Society of the State of New York. Since these photos were taken, Woodside Mansion was sold and the collection moved to the Rundel Memorial Library in Rochester. Free use.

caption: 1850s Maternity dress front & back.
description: A very elegant maternity dress was probably made by a professional in the mid-1800s. The back looks like an ordinary dress with a fitted bodice and a gathered skirt. Tiny, unseen, fabric belt ends are sewn into the inner side seams and pinned comfortably across the stomach beneath the full front. Thus, the front fabric falls straight from shoulder to hem to ease maternal expansion, but the dress back shows the small waistline. The dress is of a charming petal design in pastels, spread across the semi-sheer yardage. A larger flower print borders the double sleeve ruffles and is in vertical rows on both sides of the center-front opening. A placket lies beneath the front opening for putting the dress on and off. At the neckline is a four-inch deep, embroidered white lawn collar and a small broach. The sleeves flow from a gathered shoulder seam to fall in a bell shape. The double ruffles at the sleeve bottoms frame an inset of white lace as a third ruffle.
source: Historic Cherry Hill, Albany, New York.

caption: Outerwear - 1850s-60s Woman's medium-toned cape of knee-length has black fringe, ca. 1850s-60s.
description: This cape has dark fringe at the edges of the collar and hem,. This cape is not exceptionally wide. The collar fringe would not trim the front opening of the cape. A darker skirt extends below her cape hem and touches the ground. It has considerable petticoats beneath. Her medium-brim bonnet has curled plumes with a ribbon edge and ties.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. )Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collection. Free use.

caption: Dress with jacket and 3-flounced skirt is above a crinoline hoop. New style tiny bonnet. 1856.
description: We see the strong circle of padded wire on the lower edge of a girl’s crinoline beneath her three-tiered outer skirt. This sketchy drawing shows very short gloves, and sleeves with a large circular flare from the elbow over engageants. Her jacket may only be waist length with 3 decorative bars across the front where buttons secure it on right and left sides. A tiny, hooped bonnet with very little brim has a small bavolet ruffle across her neck. Very wide ribbon ties are floating in the breeze. Bootees cover her feet up to her ankles.
source: from PUNCH, Nov. 1856. FREE USE.

caption: Julia Ann Baird in a checkered dress holds a pretty hat in her hand. Ca. late 1850s.
description: Julia’s hair is held neatly in place by little combs and a snood in back. Her dress of brown or black and white checks has a solid dark belt. Sleeves have shirred puffs at the top of dropped shoulder seams. Below, sleeves descend in bells to a dark trim. Gathered white engageants are beneath. A narrow white collar is fastened with a tiny broach. The little hat she holds is dark with white feathers. Scottish Julia Ann Baird (b. 1839 in Perry, Alabama) was divorced twice from unhappy marriages, and then met a fine "mostly Irish" man, Tipton Smith Neel of Kansas (seen elsewhere in this document). Born in 1833, Tipton met her in Springfield Illinois. Julia added her two daughters, Margaret J. and Millie M. to Neel's first daughter, Sarah F. Neel. Tipton died suddenly in 1878. In her widowhood, Julia and her daughters were brought happiness in conversion to the Church of Jesus Christ LDS by missionaries. She lived to old age as an Idaho pioneer.
source: From Joel Ricks and His Family, a Book of Family Genealogy.

caption: 1850s Well-to-do woman wears a fine woolen dress and batiste day cap.
description: Her woolen dress has a large skirt, but not huge petticoats. The sleeves are comfortable and loose, gathering into white linen cuffs with a matching 3-inch collar. Black silk braid trims the edge of her short caplets over the sleeves and is likely around the neck or front opening of the bodice. She is sitting down in a corset which would make a fine silhouette when standing, but, when seated, pushes up the bust into an unnatural shelf. Her fashionable, batiste day cap has double shirring beside the cheeks on the front and back of a black ribbon. Luxuriously wide, black, silk ribbons tie it on. The common hairstyle was a middle part that smoothly drapes back her shiny brown hair and swings it up into a back bun. Her left hand is set on the edge of a table at the photographer's studio beside an open book. This woman of goodly means and advanced education is thought to be Leonora Cannon Taylor (source of image lost). If so, she came to Toronto, Canada in the early 1850s as a companion to a wealthy traveler friend. Leonora, originally from the British Isle of Man, met John Taylor in the Vancouver Methodist church. A widower, John married her. Very soon Church of Jesus Christ LDS missionaries baptized them both. Taylor, in later years, became the President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
source: Source and positive identification have been lost.

caption: Bathsheba Bigler Smith in a plaid wool dress, ca. early 1850s.
description: The colors of this fine wool plaid are unknown, but Bathsheba sewed it with a plain bodice, dropped shoulders, and velvet-covered buttons. Her sleeves are wide but straight with insets of shirring at the shoulders and cuffs, piped above and below each with velvet trim. Her belt has a light-colored buckle which may be silver or gold. The neckline has a small white lace collar with a dark broach of jet and a white center of ivory (or a jewel) and narrow white cuffs. Her hair is center-parted, pulled down and back, and shows a bit of either a bow or carved horn comb that emphasizes her high bun in the back. She wears small, teardrop-hoop earrings. The very full skirt has un-pressed pleats over voluminous petticoats. Bathsheba was the wife of George A. Smith, apostle, who preached much in St. George, UT.
source: Vicky Burgess-Olson, Sister Saints (Studies in Mormon history) p. 201. (Provo, Utah, Brigham Young University Press; First Edition (1978). Free use.

caption: Hannah Daniels Job wears a simple hairstyle with center-part and small curls above each ear. She has oval, wire spectacles. ca. 1850s.
description: Hannah looks very neat in her small white collar and cuffs, with a plaid silk tie and broach at her neck. Her shiny bodice must be silk showing dropped shoulder seams with no gathering. Her glasses are a little larger than her eyes, and a watch is tucked into her velvet belt. Her bodice and ornate skirt may be separate pieces, though that was a bit unusual for the time. Hannah was the wife of Thomas Job (seen elsewhere), both of them from Wales. Carma found many items of historical clothing in a trunk left in Santaquin, Utah by Thomas Job. They were shown to Carma by Elwyn and Faris Peterson, who had possession of the trunk in Eureka, Utah, but did not know about what was in the trunk until Carma asked permission to see, and drove south to photograph items from it.
source: Photo from Bliss J. Brimley, Book of Thomas Job, (American Bible Society, 1987). Free use.

caption: Mourning mother and child in black, gray, and white plaids, ca. 1850s.
description: The mother’s mourning dress is months into the grieving period when white can be properly introduced into clothing. The fabric is an interesting plaid of black, gray, and white with varying widths of vertical stripes, a most beautiful silk. Her black straw bonnet tops a black day cap with ruffles around her face, and black flowers decorations beside her cheeks. The bonnet ties are wide, white, and long, edged with black trim. Her white collar is a crocheted petal design. Black lace fingerless gloves cover her hands. The waist ornament may be part of a belt buckle. Her sad little girl holds her mother's hand and wears a dark shadow-plaid dress with a wide boat neckline and short sleeves. Her necklace is of tiny black and white beads with a pendant, the kind of jewelry kept in families for future mourning periods.
source: Beaumont Newhall, The Daguerreotype in America (note: 1850s towns and portraits, 104 photos), Dover Publications; 3 Revised edition (June 1, 1976).

caption: Black day dress gauze with satin ruffles from the skirt of a festive dress of 1855 to 65.
description: This was a very full, floor-length skirt from an expensive day dress or ball gown of black, high-quality, figured gauze. The white flowers appear machine embroidered. The skirt was made in horizontal sections or flounces. At junctures of the four flounces, the strips of fabric are joined by an inserted and ruched ribbon of white on black satin. Those ribbons must have been carefully hand-basted together, then stitched under the sewing foot of an 1860 to 1870 make of sewing machine. Then the ribbons were gathered and sewn over the seams at the top of each flounce.
source: A large bundle of 1800s scraps was given to Carma in about 1980 from a friend. Only parts of the skirt remained but they were full of obvious beauty and evident excitement. It was not known if there had been a bodice to make this a complete dress. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: A modest blouse with many buttons and cap sleeves, worn by talented, intellectual, Martha Spence, ca. 1850s.
description: This remarkable woman of intelligence and substantial sewing abilities made her own clothing. Flared caplets are sewn into the tops of long, cuffed sleeves. Below small hoop earrings, a lace scarf around her neck is fastened by a large pale broach. Martha was born in 1812 in Dublin, Ireland, and, as a well-educated young adult, left for the U.S. with her sister. The courageous girls arrived in New York without a cent between them, but Martha immediately worked as a seamstress and tailor. The sisters accepted Church of Jesus Christ LDS and traveled to Kanesville, Iowa, where Martha was a journalist for The Frontier Guardian newspaper. Later, in Utah, Martha married Howard Leland Heywood. She was an intellectual light, much appreciated for her abilities to teach young and old, and one of the most highly qualified teachers in Utah! Her grief was that she could not get books to teach French.
source: Photo and partial biography on Internet: www.uen.org/utah_history_encyclopedia/h/HEYWOOD_MARTHA.shtml.

caption: An over-blouse, called a canazou, is worn for warmth or enhancement over a daytime dress. 1840s-60s
description: This light addition to a dress has a V-shaped bodice design with a ribbon bow around the waist and an embroidered collar. Canazous were either sleeveless, like very large collar-shawls, or had short or long straight sleeves. On this example, lines of embroidery and/or lace go from the shoulders to the waistline. Likely, the same decors are in back. Dainty buttons close a front placket. If the bodice of a dress became damaged, a canazou could be a convenient and pretty cover-up. It might also be used for cooler weather and drafty homes.
source: From The Ladies Self Instructor, by R. L. Shep, editor, author, Ladies' Self Instructor in Millinery & Mantua Making, Embroidery & Applique (1853? Illustrated With the Original Engravings and Additional Illustrations. Revised Edition 1988)

caption: Teen dress with self-piping and cartridge pleated skirt. Ca. 1850s.
description: Eight bodice darts are emphasized by exceedingly narrow self-piping, called “organ-pipe" pleats, as the darts open into pleats just below the bust line. This silk dress bodice for a teenage girl is entirely hand sewn by amazingly tiny hand stitches, observable with slightly off-color thread. The gathering of the skirt is an excellent example of “cartridge pleating”, in which several rows of short in-and-out stitches are gathered together to make “cartridge” shaped pleats that extend down onto the skirt 1 or 2 inches. This dress view also shows quarter-inch self-piping around the waistline where the bodice and skirt meet in a V-shape. Cartridge pleats are more slimming over the hips than regular gathering, as the pleats can be formed to be as narrow as the hips are for that extra two inches. Regular gathering bursts out directly from the waist seam and emphasizes hip-width.
source: SOURCE: This image is from the huge clothing collection of the State Historical Society of Louisiana, New Orleans. Photo by Carma. Free use. Cartridge pleating directions are online at: http://www.elizabethancostume.net/cartpleat/

caption: Underwear of the last half of 1800s.
description: This model wears a knee-length chemise next to her skin. It is embroidered and edged with lace and has tiny puffed sleeves. This chemise is off-the-shoulder to accommodate formal gowns of that period, while day-chemises would have square or higher necklines, especially in cool weather. The model holds a corset, which she will put on over her chemise. Since the shoulders were bare and bras had not yet been invented, the corset supported her breasts, as seen below. Over her corset, she will add petticoats, and perhaps a hooped-skirt. Her ruffled pantalets descend below the chemise almost to the ankles. Bottom ruffles are embellished with tucks and lace. The pantalets have two separate legs and are open at the crotch to facilitate body functions while the hands and arms are free to hold the gown and petticoats aside. She also wears white silk stockings. For menstrual needs, women wore cloth pads against the body, held in place by cloth bands. Before toilet paper was invented in 1857, most western people used corncobs, grass, leaves or dirt. Some of the wealthy may have afforded washable rags. (Google)
source: Photo of an exhibit at Texas Tech University Museum, shown in - Betty J. Mills, Calico Chronicle, Texas Women and their Fashions ( Lubbock, Texas, Texas Tech Press, 1985).

caption: A best corset of late 1850s has adjustable laces in back, and convenient hooks in front.
description: This corset was made specifically for a certain woman's body measurements. The fabric could be washable cotton or linen on the inside and satin-weave cotton on the outside for a woman of some means. This would not always be white, as some women ordered a cheerful print or favorite color of fabric. Laces in back were adjusted by a friend or maid, then the woman could fasten herself in front. Flexible stiffness is added in casings of fabric all around that contain insertions of “whalebone” (baleen--the long, thin straining "teeth" of a whale's mouth). Baleen was long-lasting and helped ensure a small waist over full hips, with erectness in front to prevent wrinkles. Exaggerated hips were sewn to flare outward, thus further emphasizing the small waistline. In the early 1800s, corsets flared up and out from the waist to support but not cover the breasts, allowing for a deep décolletage and breasts swelling above a low neckline (much seen in Regency clothing). Later, breasts were covered, allowing for padding over small bosoms. Even today, research shows that a wide ratio of bust & hip to waistline is especially attractive to men -- thus the unhealthy 1800s crushing of waist and ribs. Breathing and eating were difficult, causing a lot of “feminine fainting,” and damage to internal organs.” (But who ever claimed fashion was intelligent?)
source: Seen online under “1800s corsets” in scores of styles and colors.

caption: More corset styles, compare between the decades.
description: Waistlines are cinched ever smaller, while corset tops become higher to match neckline fashions.
source: online under “1800s corsets” in scores of styles and colors.

caption: Internal organs were deformed by Corsets.
description: Deformation by corset was used to obtain a fashionably small waistline. Corsets were very bad for the health of digestive functions, dangerous during pregnancy, a problem for stomach, liver, and spleen, and the root cause of so much fainting, breathlessness, and the idea that women were fragile creatures. Working women wore loose or no corsets. Image online in several places to illustrate the harm of Corsets 1800s. Fashion has never had much to do with intelligence over style.

caption: Pantalets under chemises.
description: Throughout the 1800s, the most common item of underclothing was a chemise, a sort of slip that reached from shoulder to calf, and might have sleeves, depending on the weather. For the poor, a chemise had no ornamentation other than a drawstring at the top and was often used as a nightgown, as well. The wealthy decorated it with tucks and lace. The top might be cut closer to the neck, or dropped over the shoulder, as here. Women who could afford them also wore pantalets, leg coverings for each leg, attached to each other only at the waistline front and back, with buttons or ties. This left the crotch open for toilet functions, and a woman’s hands free to lift the extensive petticoats and crinolines. (They wore cloth bands and folded cloths for menstruation.) The hem of the pantalet could be ruffled with lace and embroidery as at left.

caption: Woman's pantalet edging of filet crochet, ca. 1850-1900.
description: This excellent crocheting in a slanted filet pattern makes a repeat design on the edge of strong, white, cotton pantalets.
source: Donated to Carma from East Coast antique collection by Beverly Warner. Restored with careful sewing in 140 denier thread so repairs would not show, Used in Carma's historical fashion shows. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: 1850s Quilted petticoat of glazed cotton, 4 views
description: 1 Entire petticoat. Quilted for warmth. 2 Waistband with a button. 3 Outside of hem with a much-worn tape binding. 4 Inside of hem. Rose fabric was not long enough, so a band of green was added to the inner length. DESCRIPTION: A pretty petticoat may not be seen, but adds to the pleasure of the wearer. A padded and quilted petticoat gave warmth and fullness, as seen in color images from an early Utah settlement. A rose outer fabric is padded with stretched and thinned "rolags," of the carded wool. A green, printed cotton as a partial inside lining increases the durability of the garment. It is more broadly padded from the lower half to the hem from wool that was carded to smooth the fibers. The structure requires a strong cotton fabric waistband with a handy metal button. The bottom edge is bound in woven black woolen tapes and narrow strips of cloth. Only small anchoring stitches keep the fibers carefully in place; it is not closely quilted. The curator at the Museum in Fairview, Utah, wondered if it could have been padded with alpaca fibers rather than Utah's ordinary 2 or 3 kinds of sheep wool. Carma doubted alpaca use, since NO alpacas came with early pioneers, and were unknown in Utah until recently.
source: Petticoat seen in the Fairview, Utah DUP Museum. Photos by Carma. Free use.

caption: Quilted pioneer petticoat owned by Amanda Armstrong Faucett Sanders. Ca. 1850.
description: The outer skirt fabric was mustard gold alpaca for warmth, lined in bright green cotton with tiny star prints. Gold quilting thread was used, and a 3/4 inch metal button at the waist. It was fashioned out of various widths of fabric sewn together to make an A-line shape and then the top was pleated only a little onto the waistband fabric, which was light brown and white woven cotton. To make the petticoat stiffer in its 31-inch length, the upper section shows diagonal quilting lines all on a slant with less cotton or wool padding near the waistline. The lower-center band of quilting has multiple "seashells" or "clouds," while the bottom has horizontal stitching in 6 bands, 1 inch wide, to hold the petticoat (and thus the dress) out more fully. This quilting pattern shows the artistry of a highly experienced seamstress, who bound the hemline with 1-inch wide velvet of dark brown or originally black. It is a similar quilting pattern to the glazed rose cotton petticoat above.
source: Fairview, Utah, DUP Museum, Courtesy of Nancy West. Drawn on-site by Carma. Free use.

caption: Crinolines were made of wire hoops arranged in graduated sizes held with vertical tapes. Ca.1850s & 60.
description: Brass or steel (occasionally bamboo) hoops are enclosed in fabric casings and have vertical heavy linen tapes to hold them horizontally. This one adds a ruffle at the bottom. Around the waist is a tape that is tied or buttoned for comfort. The wires do not extend over the stomach, so a woman can sit without her hoop bulging forward. When it wasn’t being worn, the hoop could collapse into a flat circle for storage. Usually, petticoats were worn over the hoops to smooth the surface of the skirt. In the 60s, hoops became enormously wide, shown in many parody illustrations of hoops seven ft. in diameter, requiring that a dress be lowered over the upper body by two maids on stools with longs sticks and pulleys (shown in 1860s fashion.)
source: Crinoline drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Women’s hairstyles-- 1850s
description: LEFT - Woven plaits of hair on each side of her part. A front section is divided into seven strands, which are expertly woven together into a wide, flat plait, then folded under to hang at ear level. She also has a fine, high, bun comb which rises three inches. SOURCE: Unidentified Ancestor of W. Mike Nielson of Provo, Utah. Free use. RIGHT - Simple swaged-back side hair, drawn into a high back bun on Mary Ann Frost Stearns, ca. 1830s to 1850s. This was a simple, common style, featuring varying sizes of side swags, some of them extremely poofed out (more examples pg 56 above). Mary Ann also wears a tiny pin on her round high collar over a plaid dress. Mary Ann was a young widow planning to go west with her 4-month-old daughter, when Parley P. Pratt, a sudden widower himself, arrived in Kirtland, Ohio. After a brief acquaintance, Parley proposed marriage. Their ceremony took place under a tree, performed by Fredrick Granger Williams. Having no mirror, Mary made herself as presentable as possible for her wedding. They enjoyed deep and happy companionship in their marriage. She cared for their small, children as they traveled around the world on missionary journeys.

caption: Curled hair of 1850s
description: Young women have center parts and curls on the sides. Popular hairstyles of this decade always had center parts. From there hair was made to stand out on the sides, either in poofs or curls. These girls have ringlets of their own hair, not hairpieces. Left, the girl has waves from her center part to her ear-tops, then loose ringlets to the shoulder. Right, the girl has straight hair for only 2 or 3 inches before her rows of vertical ringlets begin. Both girls have buns, twists, or braided hair in the back making a high formation.
source: Found online under 1850s Hairstyles, usually on Pinterest sites.

caption: Women's hair in braids around her ears or in back. 1840s to 1860s
description: Women or older teens with long enough front hair could braid it and wrap it in separate coils over their ears. In the back, she could twist, curl, or configure hair in a bun or attractive shape. A standing comb in back would help hold a bun in place. Simple, highly polished combs reflected an attractive and romantic shine in the candlelight. American women usually matched western Europeans in hairstyles with fairly distinct front and back sections and a center part. Woman's or older teen's uncut hair usually had curls of some sort on front sides. If they had ringlets, they sometimes laid them behind the ears. Back hair is up in a braided ring or twisted in a bun.
source: Both drawn by Carma from multiple sources. Free use.

caption: Jane Sneider Richards in a poofed-back day cap works on a quilt while her baby plays at her feet. 1850s.
description: Jane’s day cap has a large poof in back to hold her bun or other hair configuration. With a center part, her hair is combed down and back beneath sides frilled with double ruffles. Her dress is pink polished cotton with a red, scalloped flange going from center waist back to center waist front. The same red flange is repeated on her hem, with two other large tucks in the skirt. She wears a lace collar. Her sleeves have 4 or 5 tucks below the shoulder seam, and a point on the back of her wrist. The baby’s dress is short-sleeved, short hemmed cotton. A sheer cap is edged with lace and tied beneath the chin. Little socks or booties keep feet warm.
source: Labor of love, an oil painting by Lynde Madsen Mott, 1850s.

caption: Fancy indoor day cap with lappets, and a fine outdoor straw bonnet with ribbons. Ca. 1853.
description: Left - The cap with lappets has elegant embroidery on a fine cotton lawn with only a square of fabric to cover the top hair over a large bun or curls. Right is a beautiful, bleached straw bonnet. (Straw is bleached by putting it under a container in which the fumes of burning sulfur turn the straw completely white.) On this bonnet are bands of shirred ribbon over the brim. The silk fabric poof in back covers the bun and has a bavolet ruffle almost as long as the brim. On the side of the bonnet is a huge silk ribbon bow of many loops and long hangings. The ribbon could be of stripes or solid color and could be tied under the chin, but only hangs here for show.
source: By R. L. Shep, author, editor, Ladies' Self Instructor in Millinery & Mantua Making, Embroidery & Applique, (1853, Illustrated With the Original Engravings and Additional Illustrations, Revised Edition 1988)

caption: Lucy Mack Smith, 1853, in an engraving made after several family deaths.
description: Middle-aged Lucy is drawn by Piercy from England, and shows her mourning state by wearing some black. Her day cap is accented by black ribbons. A white silk neck shawl is folded and pinned around her shoulders with a straight pin, covering her bodice. She sits, wearing a woolen dress of narrow black and grey stripes. The heavy shawl hanging from her back has irregular sizes of black stripes. Full petticoats puff out her skirt.
source: Frederick Hawkins Piercy, Route from Liverpool to the Great Salt Lake Valley, (U.K., Ulan Press August 31, 2012) Note: Ulan Press no longer exists as a separate entity. Amazon is reprinting their books on demand.

caption: Mourning day cap of ruched ribbons with black velvet bands on back section. Ca. mid-1800s.
description: White day cap of silk satin ribbons gathered onto a base. Around each side of the back section are three rows of black velvet ribbon. Black guipure lace hangs beneath the back as well. Black and white together indicate half-mourning during the final year -- if the woman is observing two years of formal mourning. Wide silk ribbons below the ear-bow can tie or hang loose.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Woman's Leghorn hat with a brim half-covered in small feathers and a very wide ribbon of any dark color, ca. 1840s to 1860s.
description: Leghorn straw originated in Italy in what is now called Livorno, with straw cut lengthwise in very narrow strips and woven densely and smoothly into large hats or large bonnets for Britain, Europe, and America. These practical and majestic large-brimmed hats were romantic on women in garden parties of summer or fall. As skirts later ballooned with crinolines in the later 1850, hats became smaller.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Spring bonnet with flowers inside the brim, ca. 1853.
description: A spring bonnet with a round brim is woven of fancy colored straw with a sloping profile. Large, silk, gauze ribbons tie beneath her chin. It is augmented with the 1840s-50s fashion of putting flowers inside the brim, especially near the cheeks, framing a lovely face with lovely flowers. Blush-colored blossoms are attached all around the inner brim. Extra gauze bows decorate the lower left and upper right brim as we see it. Another large bow is attached outside, with ends trailing down. This kind of bonnet could be modified for a poor woman with fewer artificial flowers and fewer valuable ribbons.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Wealthy teen girl's bonnet, 1850s.
description: In a grayscale image we cannot tell whether this is a black mourning bonnet or simply of dark maroon, purple, or navy blue. The round brim itself is tightly pleated outside, with double ruched white lace on the inside edge of the brim. Silk flower buds are inside the brim at eye level, with beaded sprays and ribbons extending beyond the edge. In those decades, it seems that the bonnet dictum for higher fashion was “the more the merrier.” Such a bonnet was a frame for the face, rather than a protection for the head. She wears a beautiful lace collar and broach, partly obscured by the wide, silk, bonnet ribbons. We can guess at her youth by the narrowness of her shoulders and her flawless skin.
source: Online under 1850 girl's bonnets

caption: Bonnet of sheer silk with exterior hoops, ca. 1855.
description: The height of fashion in the Mid-1800s was a sheer bonnet. This daguerreotype of Mrs. Joseph Elisha Whitman Sr. and son Joseph shows such a bonnet with flowers inside the brim near the cheeks, and ruffles or flowers outside the hoops attached to a band. A light-colored 3-inch-wide ribbon ties under her chin. Her cape is silk with a four-inch silk fringe around the collar and an intricate pattern of braid on the collar and front. Son Joseph wears a proper cover-all bib over his little plaid dress. Note the wedding ring on her right forefinger, a common European custom, especially in the Netherlands. Her eyes gazing downward rather than toward the viewer adds a sense of thoughtful intimacy. With cheeks covered in freckles, her hair is probably auburn. She wears a ring on her index finger.
source: From Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities in Boston, Massachusetts. From the collection of Beaumont Newhall Daguerreotypes.

caption: Eliza Rebecca Robinson Wells in a very elaborate bonnet, 1854.
description: Eliza’s daguerreotype was taken in 1854 when she was no longer a slim young girl. Her fine bonnet was trimmed on one side by looped ribbon, with matching tie-ons of the same, striped ribbons. The opposite side boasts artificial flowers and dark lace. There is no day-cap beneath the bonnet, but a sheer frill is attached across the top of the inner brim. Eliza's, dark cape is topped by a white collar of ruffle-edged lace. Note that her hair is in the popular ‘50s style of center part with wide, smooth poofs swinging down and back on each side. Eliza wed young Daniel Wells in 1835 in Commerce, Illinois. Daniel had purchased much land there to sell as he platted-out the town for colonization by LDS converts. Commerce became Nauvoo. In 1844, it was the largest city in Illinois with a population of 12,000, while Chicago had only 3000. The Wells family converts were better off financially than most of Nauvoo.
source: Internet address -- www. Pinterest. com/pin/276689970833096721/

caption: Home-made bonnet on Patty Bartlett Sessions, an early midwife who delivered almost 4000 babies. 1850s.
description: Despite old age and the fashions toward the end of the century, Patty Bartlett Sessions still enjoyed the buds and fancies tucked into dark lace and ribbon around her face on the inside brim of her bonnet. This bonnet is probably silk stretched over buckram for stiffening and was used for many years by refreshing the silk and silk ribbon tie-ons as they wore out. Such bonnets were out of fashion by 1866, but the latest fashion was apparently not as important to Patty as many other things, such as delivering thousands of babies for Church members going west. She married David Sessions in Bethel, Maine, in 1836 and raised her own 8 children through the years (only 3 survived to adulthood). Patty’s many diaries give a vivid picture of pioneer life.
source: Data from internet. Image is believed to be from Church of Jesus Christ LDS archives. It also appears under her entry on Wikipedia, wikipedia.org/wiki/Patty_Bartlett_Sessions#Family.

caption: Wilfred Woodruff gave this love-gift broach to his wife Phebe, with a lock of his hair in the back, ca. 1850s
description: A small gold frame with a daguerreotype portrait has a reverse side with a lock of Wilfred's hair curled inside the back compartment. A thin glass dome covers the portrait, and flat glass protects the hair. Thus, Phebe kept a memento of her husband pinned close to her heart during his long absences. Though common, this was a very important symbol of love in the 1800s. Decorations featuring the hair of a loved one were personal and precious, as no one else could give an actual bit of one’s own self as a message of devotion.
source: Thought to be from Daughters of the Utah Pioneers Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Sunglass spectacles with a metal case for protection, ca. mid -1800s.
description: Note the small transparent circles in the center of the lenses. These were regular lenses to clarify vision, although they were tinted. The rest of the lens seems to be frosted for extra light tinted to protect sensitive eyes.
source: Donated by Abbie H. Wells to Salt Lake City DUP Museum, #11342-002. Scan by Carma. Free use.

caption: Purchased at an antique store in downtown Provo, Utah. Carma gave this and all other interesting fans to the BYU Fine Arts Historic Clothing Collection.
description: This bamboo fan is supported by bamboo sticks. The opposite side of the fan has copies of Sang Dynasty Chinese characters printed on it. The Chinese exported such fans all over the world into different cultures. This was part of several mourning accessories that came to Utah with Norwegians immigrants to Spanish Fork, Utah.
source: Purchased at an antique store in downtown Provo, Utah. Carma gave this and all other interesting fans to the BYU Fine Arts Historic Clothing Collection.

caption: Fur tippet of medium length, to wear over the shoulders as a mark of affluence and beauty, ca. Mid 1820-70s
description: A tippet can be of fur or of fabric ruffles to adorn a dress for visiting and walking. They were often seen in good weather as women's carriage- wear.
source: R. L. Shep, author, editor, Ladies' Self Instructor in Millinery & Mantua Making, Embroidery & Applique, (1853, Illustrated With the Original Engravings and Additional Illustrations, Revised Edition 1988.

caption: A black crocheted wool shawl with an almost 4-inch fringe. A detail.
description: Women set great store by their handiwork with needles, hooks, yarns, and threads. This black, crocheted shawl was found in an old trunk belonging to Thomas Job in the small Utah town of Santaquin. With larger skirts of the 1850s, long coats were out of the question. So most women wore shawls for warmth that would spread over their skirts as far down as they wished. This lace-like shawl was made for beauty, probably by Thomas’s wife Elizabeth.
source: From the Thomas Job trunk, Santaquin UT.

caption: Flat handbag done in needlepoint “Berlin work” on canvas, ca. 1800s.
description: A square needlepoint on canvas makes a flat handbag. This close wool stitching was done in black, pale and dark blue and brown with line-dots of yellow. It is bound with black silk handles.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Victorian summer reticule. Ca. 1850-1890.
description: Embroidery on heavy white satin makes the flowers and leaves seem realistic on this reticule wrist-bag. Larger flowers along the bottom are made of tightly gathered ribbons and stand out in bold relief. The fabric is carefully self-fringed on three sides, with a casing for the ribbon drawstrings, Creative designer, Jeanette Wolf, an intricate hand-seamstress, made this lovely reproduction piece in Provo, Utah. She has taken top prizes in state fairs for her incredibly precise fabric work in her unique styles.
source: Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Crocheted silk purse of Eliza R Snow. Ca. 1850s to 60s.
description: This purse of blue silk floss is crocheted into a deep bag with double yarn drawstring handles and pink and blue fringe around all edges. The name, E R Snow, is cleverly crocheted into the design using pink floss, which requires much careful knotting of the silk threads as the crocheting is in process. The remarkable Eliza enjoyed doing difficult things! The little bag is lined in pale pink silk to show through the blue stitches. It measures about 9 inches deep and 5 inches wide.
source: #1182 Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Blue and white brocaded silk satin ribbon. Ca. 1850s to 1890s.
description: Cream satin ribbon with brocaded figures was undoubtedly purchased at great cost from France, Tiny, pale blue clovers in the center are edged by larger, deeper blue flowers and leaves on the borders. Knobbed edges form an elegant finishing touch on a ribbon about 2 ½ inches wide. France provided all silk ribbons until 1900. This was likely brought from the Eastern States and kept simply to gaze upon, not ever used for a woman to wear, or it would not be in such fine condition today!
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum #14121-025. Ribbon belonged to the family of Joseph Lafayette Rawlins, a Delegate and Senator from Utah with enough wealth that his family could afford such ribbon. Donor, Lynn Kent. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Pink taffeta parasol belonged to the family of Joseph Lafayette Rawlins, a native pioneer of 1850.
description: The wide edgings of scissor-pinked, shaggy strips of fabric were on both handle and ferrule of varnished golden oak. This had to have been brought west from markets on the East Coast and used for dressy garden parties through the 1870s.
source: SLC DUP Museum, #14121-002. Photo enhancement by Lorie Davis.

caption: A beige marketing bag is crocheted of soft bark fibers. It hangs over a blue and green wool, plaid shawl. Made in mid-1850s.
description: Flexible, thin strips of bark fiber are made into a rough yarn which can be worked into handy accessories, such as this expandable, crocheted bag. Generous-sized and tough, a mesh bag for marketing required sturdy fabric around the top and handles to protect the carrier’s hands during a walk to and from the market. A plaid shawl hanging beneath the bag is lightweight for most of the year in Utah and is hand-stitched to keep self-fringing from fraying too deeply into the fabric. These were common among peasants and pioneers of many decades.
source: Photo by Carma in original pioneer cabin in Salt Lake City, Utah, a Church of Jesus Christ LDS Historical Site. Free use.

caption: Leather bootee with elastic insertion and stacked French heel. Ca. 1840-1850s.
description: Elastic became available in clothing after 1835, and here helps ease on a shoe that would otherwise require laces or buttons. A silk cord rosette above the square toe provides a feminine detail. An ankle loop in back helps pull it completely on. A "French" heel has an hour-glass curve on all its sides. This stacked wooden heel is about 2 ½ inches high. Some bootee shapes were much fancier, made of silk with huge rosettes of ruffled circles of narrow ribbon--3 or 4-inches of repeated ruffles -- centered with a round covered button. Many bootees were heavy silk of pink, blue, or lavender covering the front half; but matching, dyed leather covered the back half of the bootee.
source: Drawn by Carma, after Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York, Theater Arts Books, 1969) Free use.

caption: A Women’s boot too low-cut to be called a bootee. Ca. 1840-1890.
description: This low boot is dressy, of dark, silk moiré with patent leather toe caps, and a band of patent along the side. Fine silk cord laces up the inside foot in very small eyelets. Heels are just a flat, leather reinforcement. This style could be pre-manufactured and quickly available in teen's or lady's size.
source: Drawn by Carma from an unknown advertisement. Free use.

caption: A woman's machine-made nightgown from 1856, though the style was worn most of the 1800s, and made by hand stitching.
description: This American or European cotton nightgown has a very pretty edging of Swiss embroidered ruffle around the high neck and down to the waist, as well as on the cuffs. Small lingerie shell buttons extend completely from neck to hem. The front shoulder yoke shows gracefully arched curves above bust-line gathers. More gathers are at the top insertion of the sleeves with less obvious gathers at the cuffs. The gown appears to be about ankle length. Sewing machines were created in 1846. Soon after, they were used in clothing manufacturing. This nightgown was sewn on a machine. However, the same pattern would have been popular and made by hand before machines were available.
source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Nightgown Date: ca. 1856, Accession Number: C.I.41.125.24. Gift of the Misses Dorcas & Katherine Beer in 1941. Online at: http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/108968?rpp=20&pg=3&ft=silk+nightgown&pos=56. Public Domain.

caption:
In unheated homes, bedtime warmth for the head and ears was a necessity to both men and women.
Men wore conical nightcaps. Date: centuries!
description: 1850  Night bonnet is used only for sleeping; American woman’s snug, cotton nightcap.

caption: Summer nightgown Met Museum, ca 1830-1850s
description: This cooler, summer nightgown of fine linen is topped by a ruffled oval neckline on a double-layer yoke with off-shoulder sleeve seams. Two buttons on the yoke are for design only. Sleeves are puffed at top and bottom seams, with a ribbon-like insert or addition over the bottom ruffle. Below the yoke, the gown is gathered only at the center 2/3ds to leave the underarms flat and comfortable. It appears that the gown is pulled on over the head. Although this specific gown is dated in the mid-1830s, this style would have been popular for many decades after.
source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Gift of Mrs. Albert S. Morrow, 1937. Accession Number: C.I.37.45.73.

caption: 1851 Elaborate trousseau nightgown in linen cambric, newest style 1851
description: A wealthy newlywed’s long nightgown. For ease in stepping into this gown, it has a long, frilled, center-front placket with many buttons beneath the ruffled, embroidered edge. The shoulders are completely yoked in scallops with embroidery. Gathering of the body fabric is made in many long vertical tucks that release at thigh length. Around the neckline is a ruffled, stand-up collar for more warmth. Narrow cuffs gather fullness at the wrists, all with embroidery and frills. Ankle length.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840). Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Coll. Free use.

caption: Collar yoke for a nightgown.
description: This elaborately hand-embroidered yoke for a nightgown may have been made in anticipation of a wedding, or simply as a way to use evening hours in a beautiful pursuit. The gown would have been attached later. Also, as an old gown wore out, the beautiful yoke could be re-used on a new lower-gown. However, it appears to have never been attached to a gown.
source: Made by Minerva Wade Hickman, daughter of Moses Wade of the Mormon Battalion. Donor, Maria K. Nash. DUP Museum, Salt Lake City, UT.

caption: Simple, long baby dress for boy or girl, a gathered back view, ca. 1850s.
description: This long baby dress is made of extra quality muslin with drawstrings in the back bodice only to adjust for proper fit. This dress is not excessively long. If it were a dress of the wealthy, it would have much embroidery and lace on the bodice and sleeves and much greater length. The front yoke is plain and not gathered, although the skirt below the yoke is softly gathered.
source: Purchased as an antique in Massachusetts by Carma; it was donated to the BYU Fine Arts Historic Clothing Collection. Drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Baby bootie of the 1850s
description: The stiffened bootie is of colored satin. Perforated and embroidered trim circle the ankle and meet at the shoe opening, which ties with a tassel. The toe section is flat with more decorative perforations.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Baby's christening bonnet of wide lace, with back seam sewed closed. Ca. Mid-1800s.
description: A wide, straight section of bobbin or pillow lace from Ireland (12 to 14 inches long) is folded in half length-wise and sewn together on one side. Elegant enough for baby’s christening, drawstrings of ribbon tie around the face and the neck to fit it to the infant’s head. It would cover the ears. This bonnet folds flat when not being worn. By definition, a cap covers the head, with or without a brim. But a bonnet also ties under the chin, as this one does.
source: The Ulster National Museum of Ireland. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: American baby bonnet of 1850s.
description: This dainty bonnet is made of fine, embroidered cotton strips sewn together. Especially nice is 1½ inch smooth edging near the face that has repeated rose petals or leaves embroidered all around it. A ruffle of narrow lace is gathered onto the edge to surround the baby's face. A pink, silk ribbon outlines the top and ties beneath the chin.
source: Drawn by Carma. An out-of-town friend brought this antique to Carma so she could examine it closely and illustrate it. Free use.

caption: Toddler's tucked dress for boy or girl with eyelet embroidered sleeves. Mid-1800s.
description: This dress has a ribbon sewn across the yoke. Sleeves are ornate eyelet beside the neckline and over the shoulders to the upper arms. There are tucks and more eyelet trim at the scalloped edges of the sleeves. Several tucks at the hemline would lengthen or shorten the skirt to the tops of short stockings on a little child. Boys of this age are just as likely to be coddled with prettiness and opulence in dresses until "breeched" into short pants at age 4 to 6. A child of sufficient wealth to have this dress would also wear pantalets seen beneath the hem -- until the 1870s, at least.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840). Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Lewis Williams at age two or three, ca. 1850s.
description: This young relative of Frederick G Williams II has many expensive buttons sewn on grosgrain ribbons which are applied to his dress. A frill of lace edges his elbow-length sleeves, and his skirt is short enough to allow him to toddle around. It is hard to see the bit of white collar and a black silk bow almost covered by his chin. This must have been a tedious form of photography because this little boy born in 1855 looks a bit anxious. His dark brown eyes are intelligent, and his hair, gathered into a knot on top, is long in the back. This old photo has been scratched over the years, but the hair and dress are still interesting.
source: Courtesy of Frederick G. Williams III. Free use. We can no longer find this image, but notes identify that it was “from online Williams’ family history of long ago.”

caption: Baby dress with soutache braid on cream fabric, ca. 1850.
description: This baby dress could be a fine wool in peach color or pale yellow delaine*, and the dark soutache braid is intricately sewn on for decoration. The girl’s hair is parted in the middle and possibly French-braided from her forehead to hang down in the back, or is shorter and just tucked behind her ears. (Baby is not amused.) Mother, perfectly coifed with ringlets in the back, wears a dark velvet dress, dark bracelet, gold broach, and dangling earrings. Puffed engageants with center trim extend below her pagoda sleeves.
source: This Daguerreotype is in the Wisconsin Historical Society Headquarters, Madison, Wisconsin, # [X3] 35904.

caption: Mrs. Tipton Neel holds their baby girl while wearing lovely accessories. Ca. late 1850s.
description: Baby girl, Sarah F. has the simplest possible dress, which could be knitted or crocheted, or of tiny checks. It has a drawstring neckline and gathered sleeves descending into cuffs. She holds her dolly unsteadily in her left hand. Her hair has been combed into a curl on top of her head. Mrs. Neel has a beautiful Ayrshire linen collar, about 5 inches wide, tied around her neck by a narrow velvet ribbon above the bodice neckline. A decorative shawl of the dress fabric is bound in a light color and slipped over the dress with a fastening in the center front. It probably adds much interest to the back of the dress. She wears black lace fingerless gloves on the hands wrapped around her child. Her hair is center-parted and arranged in two side drapes which are drawn up into her high bun in back. This first wife of Tipton Neel died after bearing him this one daughter. Sometime later he met his second wife, Julia Ann Baird, shown elsewhere.
source: Ricks’ Family genealogy information. Free use.

caption: Toddler’s dress of patchwork pieces. 1850s.
description: A patchwork dress is made from leftovers of old clothing from a family of 11 children. It was worn by 2 little boys in succession, as each baby grew to fit it. Brown prints are seen in the front bodice, with tiny shell buttons. The skirt is of squares and made long enough to shorten or lengthen with a tuck. Of almost fifty different prints and weaves, a few squares of bright yellow and orange match an orange binding around the waistline. The skirt was sewn onto the bodice after the bodice edge was piped. The most worn-out tell their own story of children's arms being thrust into old, fragile fabrics. Some tearing was inevitable and beyond mending. This dress made by necessity was saved for a keepsake to remember the children who wore it. The compacted history of each of these fabrics is especially important, as each bit of cloth showed its last artful use. The variety of colors and designs makes it a supreme accomplishment of devoted LDS-American folk artists.
source: Dress made by Eliza Dorsey Ashworth, of Yorkshire, England, after settling with her large and successful family in Salt Lake City, 1852. Shown in Mary Bywater Cross, p. 87 Quilts and Women of the Mormon Migrations, Treasures of Transition, Nashville, Tennessee (Rutledge Press, 1996). Free use.

caption: Baby shoe of pale blue, dense felt. 1854.
description: This shoe has scallops and four tiny buttons for fastening. The edge of the scallops and top of the shoe are reinforced with top-stitching. The ankle section is made of pale blue felt, with the toes and heels of blue-gray felt. It was worn by little Josephine McLaughlin in a large oil painting in Banfield, Illinois. It was part of the center room decorations of an elite restaurant in that city.
source: Seen by Carma in the 1960s from an antique painting in a restaurant. Ever alert to antique clothing, she sketched the shoe on the spot. Free use.

caption: First triplets in Utah, July 24, 1850.
description: In this Damaged daguerreotype image we see the first triplets born in Utah Territory to T. Rhoades and Mary White. Though darkened around the edges, the baby dresses are sufficiently clear to get an idea of style. In the center is Benjamin with his sisters Adeline and Adelaide on each side. All three of the baby dresses are made of a medium-color tiny print. Light bands of trim perk up the longish skirts and caplet sleeve tops over three- quarter length sleeves. There is some sort of narrow shawl or folded blanket hanging across the body of Adelaide on the right. Benjamin died at age three while the sisters lived into adulthood. Their mother, Mary Miranda White Rhoades is not clearly seen due to the staining, though she appears to be smiling.
source: Courtesy of W. Michael Nielsen of Provo. Free use.

caption: Toddler boy in dress and pantalets holds a big hat. Ca. 1850s.
description: A three-year-old boy in a linen dress, probably pale beige, called “Holland linen (or sometimes just called “Holland”). He has a wide neckline and many tiny stitched tucks, both vertical and horizontal, for decoration. A large felt hat with a fairly low crown is what little boys often wore in the 1850s. His naturally curly hair is kept medium short around his head.
source: Detail of daguerreotype in a book which has become lost. Nevertheless, its age puts it in the realm of public domain.

caption: Little boys in their best clothes. Ca. 1850.
description: With eyes full of early wisdom," these 3 and 4-year-old brothers are of a wealthy family and wear the same good fabrics of navy and beige in their differing suits of clothes. Shirts are decked out with an impressive number of expensive silver and brass buttons, and necklines are enhanced with sheer collars. Small engageants below their sleeves are of transparent netting. Dotted embroideries trim the slit sleeves of the smaller boy are fripperies produced by an adoring mother or her seamstresses.
source: American Heritage, "Children of the Young Republic, April 1960, with assorted folk art illustrations of children by the best of America," by George Clay. This volume is a revealing assessment of how European visitors to America were startled by children’s freedom of speech with a touch of impudence, choices of play, and early socializing. There were fewer parental restrictions in this well-off land. Poor children could "quit their parents" at any time they chose.

caption: Boy’s skeleton suit, ca. 1800 to 1860s
description: Throughout the 1800s boys often wore skeleton suits in America and Britain. Skeleton suits are named for being straight tubes of cloth for arms and legs, with separate tops and trousers, buttoned together at the waist. That made for convenience and ease of wear. A small child could not undress himself at will, nor become un-tucked and untidy. A mother could unfasten the back buttons for toilet use, as could an older boy. The mother could add a ring of matching fabric and more buttons around the waist as the boy grew. Or a long, tucked-in top could provide growing room. All the mother need do was lower the row of buttons to fit a taller boy, or raise the buttons for a little brother. This standard-design of suit with collar and cuffs was reproduced by Carma for the Lyon Drug and Mercantile store in Nauvoo. For display, it was made in green and white checkered linen with little ruffled cuffs and a collar of white cotton added for best dress.
source: Sewn and drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: An early skeleton suit. Ca. 1815 through all of century.
description: A little boy with his kite wears a daily outfit with a round neck ruff and high-waist jacket with double-breasted buttons. Skeleton suits, so-called for being made of straight tubes of cloth for arms and legs, had separate tops and trousers and were buttoned together at the waist. That design made for convenience and ease of wear. A small child could not undress himself at will, nor become un-tucked and untidy. A mother could unfasten the back buttons for toilet use, as could an older boy. A long, tucked-in top provided length as the boy grew. All the mother need do was lower or raise the row of buttons to fit a taller boy, or shorten the suit for a little brother. She could also add a ring of cloth and buttons around the waist.
source: ABC Coloring Book. Free use.

caption: Boy’s and girl’s day clothes on the wealthy Bowden children. Mid-1800s
description: The little boy wears pale blue, cotton velveteen trousers buttoned to the black velvet top of his skeleton suit. The trousers are made to look like the front of his father’s flat-fall trousers with buttons on each side of center. His Mama insists on a white collar with ruffled edges. White socks warm his feet and legs, and black shoes are tied with silk ribbon bows. His little sister wears a dainty white batiste dress and best muslin petticoat above the favorite red color of shoes for children, with a tiny strap and buckle.
source: Oil painting, "The Bowden children," by John Hoppner, Detroit Museum of Art.

caption: Mourning dress for a boy of 3-5 yrs, with black soutache braid trims. Ca. 1840s to 60s.
description: Black silk cord scrolls around the edges of a small boy’s mourning dress. This was a costly example of a child's dress since it was all hand-stitched. Though seen in England, a few wealthy children of America may have had such,
source: Drawn by Carma as seen in the Museum of Costume, Bath, England. Free use.

caption: A deceased little boy on a couch, about 1850.
description: This picture was taken as a keepsake soon after the child died. He is lying in his plaid shirt with a white collar and button-on pantaloons. His head rests on a pillow of sculptured velvet. The short hair, fancy pillow, and daguerreotypist coming to the home indicate that the family is probably well-to-do. Images of deceased children were common for those who could afford them. Such an image was a precious keepsake for parents who never quite recovered from their loss.
source: This is a sixth-size daguerreotype courtesy of Josephine Cobb, from “The American Daguerreotype.”

caption: Toddler's speckled stockings in shoes with two string ties at ankle and instep. Ca. 1850.
description: Wool yarns could be dyed in hanks bound tightly with occasional strings, which made for speckled yarns. This produced a pretty knitted product, photographed elsewhere.* This shoe was typical for boys and girls of toddler age.
source: Detail of William Matthew Prior, folk artist ca. 1850, National Gallery, Washington D.C. Drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: School-age boy clothing, ca. 1854
description: This son of Amasa Lyman and Louisa Maria Tanner Lyman is about 8, and wears tan wool trousers with a white, short-collared shirt and red silk ribbon bow tie with long ends. His coat is brick red and thigh length, with simple notched lapels. His plain, wide, black belt is the new elastic and has a dull pewter, elongated buckle. His golden-red hair is wavy and collar length and combed neatly away from his cheeks. The Lymans had two sons: Francis Marion and Amasa Mason Jr. This son is not identified in the painting.
source: Detail from a gigantic oil portrait on canvas of the Lyman family that hangs in the Salt Lake City DUP on the main floor. The painter of that time is unknown. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Schoolboys in matching coats. Ca. 1850.
description: Coats of drab green wool on wealthy young brothers have narrow sleeves that show a single white line of wool or silk binding at the cuff ends. It would match the unseen jacket neck binding. A white double-line outlines the placket down the front, a chevron above the cuffs and around the welt pockets. Buttons are small and brass. A narrow white shirt collar shows above the jacket. Pure white shirts and trousers are of different weights of linen or cotton. Their trousers are of a heavy cotton fabric. These boys have ear-length hair with neat side parts.
source: By Ammi Phillips, a self-taught portrait painter, exhibits his high level of American folk artwork. American Antiques Handbook.

caption: Boy’s red cape with black tape décor, ca. 1850.
description: This cape with black tape is illustrated here with other co-ordinates from Carma’s research into authentic fashion sources of the Mid-1800s. This boy in Sunday clothing would have worn white trousers of heavy cotton below a red, unshaped jacket with a white belt, often without a buckle. Black tape decorates his coat to match the cape. A pilot cap could also have been made to match. His black slippers have stockings of black mesh over other white stockings as some adult women wore. Wealthy people sometimes "gilded the lily.
source: The cape was seen in the Salt Lake City DUP exhibits. After Carma’s additions, it was painted by the artist, Margaret Weber. Free use.

caption: Boy in green jacket carrying a whimmy-diddle. Ca. 1840 to 1870.
description: The waist-length jacket has a breast pocket and one button fastener. His Shirt collar is scalloped over a black tie. Modern shoes and trousers were used, but the shoes were essentially correct, and the trousers had large buttons like the mid-1800s. (Non-accurate back pockets and center front zipper are not in view.)
source: The toy, a spinning noisemaker, was made by a Provo woodcarver. The jacket, shirt, and tie were sewn by Carma. Modeled by a boy with typical longer hair for this time. Photo by Wayne Keys. Free use.

caption: A schoolboy wears the same clothing his father would wear. Ca. 1845 - 60.
description: This suit of clothing is medium green for a young boy. His shoes are black with a small buckle and light stockings. A white shirt with a soft folded down collar has a tie with a simple square knot and trailing ends. His vest has a rounded shawl collar with small, fabric, double-breasted buttons, very close together. He even has a watch chain, as his father would have, which indicates a level of wealth. Fruit is gathered into his pilot’s cap on the ground. Side-parted hair is ear length and curved forward to his cheeks.
source: Artist and title unknown. Seen in Nina Fletcher Little, Country Art in New England, 1790-1840, (Sturbridge, Mass., Old Sturbridge Village, 1965). Outlines by Carma.

caption: “Truant Discovered.” This boy was caught skipping school by a truant officer.
description: In this woodcut print from a newspaper, the humiliated boy has run from home dressed as a girl with a nightgown and headscarf, but it didn’t save him. The judgmental truant officer in a tailcoat has dragged him home and is scolding him before his mother, in a day cap and shawl. She looks piteously at the officer and begs for mercy. His sister in a bonnet and cloak covers a laugh. Boys and men often wore plaid trousers, as this boy does. All things plaid had been popularized by Queen Victoria of Britain, who loved her Scottish home and often wore plaid dresses and shawls. Prince Albert sometimes wore plaid trousers.
source: Collected from an old newspaper in Carma’s searches. It is old enough to be public domain.

caption: Dancing children participating at an adult dancing party, ca. 1850.
description: The 1800s saw many community dances in which participants were of all ages. These well-to-do children have had dancing teachers as a regular part of their curriculum. The boy has been taught to lead a girl in the set steps of many dances and does so with dignity not seen elsewhere in his life. He has a long ruffled collar over a curved-front jacket with elbow cuffs. A longer vest beneath has many buttons. Trousers are looser, and he, too, wears dancing slippers. Slippers were worn by dancers of all ages. No clogs, oxfords, or boots on the dance floor, please! The girl is dressed in her best, off-the-shoulder, frilly dress with ruffled pantalets, long white stockings, and any color of dancing slippers.
source: Drawn by Lorie Davis from an old encyclopedia illustration of a community dance. Free use.

caption: A tiny girl in a Utah daguerreotype of 1850.
description: This tot is wearing a plaid dress with three tucks above the hem, ready to be let out as she grows taller. She has a small, white, collar and bands on her puffed sleeves. Her square-toed booties are very shiny leather. She sits on a bentwood chair, seeming to await some event. In the international fashion of 1850, this little child is wearing center-parted, smooth hair which was common on females of any age. It is probably in a bun or braid in back. Among females, day caps, as well as folk-costume caps covered smooth hair, unless hair was naturally curly and unruly.
source: Drawn by Carma from a daguerreotype of late 1840s -50s of Danish immigrants. Free use.

caption: Toddler’s best calico dress in red. White cord decorates borders. Ca. 1850s-60s.
description: Red calico dress printed with tiny gold and green flowers and embellished with white cording for a 3-year-old girl or boy. This antique is probably American made. Rounded, set-in sleeves are topped with two small white buttons and a line of cord around the shoulder seam. The same cord surrounds the neckline. Three rows of narrow white cord is hand-stitched in the semi-circles of the sleeves and at the waist where a gathered skirt attaches. Just above the hemline, all around the skirt, white cording makes sizeable leaf figures in a repeated pattern. Hand-sew stitches attach all decor perfectly.
source: Purchased as an antique to possibly be used in a historic oil painting by Lynde Madsen Mott. Photos by Carma. Free use.

caption: Dress for a small child of the mid-1800s, wool with cotton lining.
description: A red and blue wool plaid dress with a very short bodice is styled for the mid-1800s and is completely lined with cotton to reduce itching. Most modern children do not tolerate wool flannel directly against their skin as past generations had to at all times, poor things! The bodice and sleeves are cut on the bias, with a white ruffle at the wide neckline. Horizontal tucks were usual above the skirt hem to make the dress short for a small child. But during years of historical fashion shows, the tucks were let out, as seen here, to lengthen the dress as the model grew taller.
source: Made by Carma for her collection and historic fashion shows in the 1980s. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Mary E., a child pioneer in a tintype portrait.
description: This little girl has a textured, horizontal stripe in her full skirt, with probably two petticoats underneath. Her dark blouse with many little buttons may be a separate piece that has rows of gathering at the bottom where it meets the skirt. It may be sewn to the skirt to prevent gapping. The neckline has a narrow edging with a button, and her off-shoulder sleeves are gathered at the upper-arm and cuff. Her shoulder-length hair is side-parted and combed straight for this portrait. Mary’s family had to leave their home in the East, threatened by anti-Mormon mobs. She left a little note under a floorboard in childish print, saying she had taken her doll with her, and hoped that someday they could come back home again. She signed it “Mary E.” This portrait made it to the Utah Territory with her name on the back.
source: Source has been lost, but deeply touched the authors.

caption: Adolescent girl's summer dress of eyelet. Ca. 1852.
description: Eyelet embroidered bodice and sleeves are featured with over-the-shoulder sleeve insertions. Lines of eyelet lace run diagonally from shoulder to waist, with more lines of lace running crossways between. The skirt of fine muslin has multiple tucks in the hem to add more beauty, and, when necessary, extra length. One or two muslin petticoats would extend from the shoulders down, and give sufficient underwear coverage for warmer weather. The long sash is likely of silk ribbon that could be changed for color.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Adolescent girl in a semi-sheer dress, 1850s
description: Elizabeth Davies (b. 1835) about age fourteen in Llanllawddog, Carmarthenshire, Wales. Her skirt is full, and her sleeves are deeply gathered into wrist bands or shirring. We can barely see on her bodice many rows of gathered lace. A flower decorated hat on the table at right is more evidence of middle-class status, being able to afford pretty clothing. Her father owned a small woolen factory in Llangathen, on the banks of the River Towy in Carmarthenshire. The family all joined the Church of Jesus Christ LDS in the mid-1800s.
source: Photo from Bliss Brimley who collected historical pictures of her ancestors while on an LDS mission in Wales. Bliss J. Brimley, Book of Thomas Job, (American Bible Society, 1987). Free use.

caption: Adolescent girl in a checkered dress with two pet hens, 1859.
description: A determined-looking 9 or 10-year-old American girl wears a checkered dress with a high neckline and 1-inch collar of white linen and a ring broach. Her sleeves have double puffs at the top with the lower portion being long, narrow, and bias-cut for ease of movement. Below a yoke, the bodice appears to be pleated and is finished with a stiff self-belt. Her full skirt is softly pleated. Dark hair is neatly smoothed from a center part and cut evenly at back neckline length.
source: Daguerreotype, Laura M. Chamberlain, Worcester Historical Museum, R6., 1859.

caption: An adolescent wears total black mourning clothing in a tinted ambrotype portrait, ca. 1857.
description: A young woman of wealth can afford beautiful mourning clothing of the finest Kashmir mourning crepe. Joining a wide, silk-velvet collar is a gold broach. Her dress has satin flanges from shoulder to waist, and two sets of alternating wool and satin cap sleeves. Long, gathered sleeves below the caps end in short wrist cuffs. Her full skirt is softly pleated. Wide satin ribbons gather into large bows draping from in her back hair. But the loveliest clothing never mutes the pain of a loved one's death.
source: This vintage photograph was an ambrotype found on Pinterest, which says “by lisby1,” identified by Jeannette Hilberg. Public Domain.

caption: Adolescent clothing modeled on a Swiss fashion doll. Ca. 1855.
description: This doll from 1855 was pictured on a postcard, dressed for a promenade with her family in the park. She wears bell-shaped sleeves, which probably ought to have engageants beneath them for that date. A two-piece dress with a peplum on the bodice shows off white braid trim. The handbag is a miniature Berlin needlework piece, and her broad felt hat is decorated with a white plume and a dark bow under her chin. Beneath the dress is undoubtedly correct underwear. Miniature furniture is accurate in the smallest ways. Fashion dolls were popular for showing women the details of the latest fashions, created in miniature.
source: Doll postcard from the Shweiz Landesmuseum in the capital, Zurich, 1855.

caption: Teen girl’s muff & bonnet, ca. 1840s-60s.
description: A warm visiting dress is gathered to the center front, and her collar is decorated with silk braid, as are her upper sleeve caplets and lower bell-shaped sleeves. Very simple engageants have only a cuff at the wrist. She tucks her hands into a muff which could be fur or fluffy short feathers with a satin lining. Over her wrist is a tiny, densely crocheted reticule, almost diamond-shaped, with a tassel at the bottom. Her bonnet is not deep and shows tight ruching of batiste within the brim, or it could be a very ruffled day cap. A two-inch, silk, ribbon bow ties under her chin. Silky roses are on each side of the exterior bonnet, and petticoats are worn over pantalets with many tucks on the lower edges Her booties are prunella (lavender) wool or heavy silk with leather toe and heel caps. For ease, they lace up on the inside of the foot with a narrow cord.
source: This is a combination of fashion factors drawn together by Carma. Free use.

caption: Girl's silk and crocheted nightcap, ca.1858.
description: Nightcap made of wide and narrow ribbons with silk cord crocheting at the crown and front border. The primary ribbons are pink with narrow stripes on each side of a wider ribbon of pink flowers. Narrow, pink satin ribbon weaves through the lace around the face. That this cap is still in good condition makes one wonder if the girl child actually lived to wear it.
source: Made by Karen Nielsen, a pioneer. Now at Salt Lake City DUP Museum #900001-600. Donor, Pearl Anderson Hamilton.

caption: Teen dress bodice in plaid. Late 1850s.
description: This hand-stitched bodice front has fan darts for the bust line. The back shows common “wrap-over” shoulder seams and two curved "princess" seams from armhole to waistline. An attempt was made to match the plaid lines of the back pieces, a challenge with plaids. Both have the same bleached muslin lining attached. This was going to be a best dress for a young teen. For some reason, it was never finished. Perhaps the daughter died, a family problem interfered, or the girl outgrew the dress before it was assembled, all common situations.
source: Fairview, Utah Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: Girl's plaid hood or bonnet. 1850s.
description: This worn-out head-gear is shown to show its inner construction. The red, flat section may have been meant to be worn in back to cover a girl’s neck in inclement weather, making it a hood. Or, the red brim may have been turned around the opposite way as a bonnet, with the red piece shielding the face over the forehead. Note the red, wool flannel lining of the inside crown, which has a faint print. Worn-out parts in the lining disclose an interlining of black and white checkers. All the hood’s edges are bound in black velveteen, as is the remaining under-chin tie. This construction highlights the fact that every scrap of fabric that could be used was used.
source: Fairview, Utah Museum. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: 1860 working men.
description: These men wear cotton shirts with and without collars. The head openings only extend half way down the chest, as shirts of the time were all pull-on styles. Fully button-front shirts didn’t become common until the early 1900s. The shoulder seam rests down over the shoulder 2 or 3 inches, as required by the standard shirt pattern seen elsewhere in this book. The modern reproduction shirts here have fuller sleeves, gathered at shoulder and cuff, which is wider than daguerreotypes of actual shirts of the decade. Men aspiring to any fashion at all wore vests over their shirts, as the bare shirt often doubled as a night shirt, and was, therefore, “underwear.” Suspenders of all kinds held up trousers, which were now uniformly front buttoned under a fly– no more broadfall trousers, and no zippers yet. A scarf tied around the neck under the collar was standard, and men always wore hats out-of-doors. The hat top left is called a “pilot cap.”
source: United American Costume Display.

caption: Rumpled workmen cleaning a sewer, ca. 1860.
description: Wearing dirty hip boots of heavy leather, the center man has an open shirt over thick underwear and a narrow tie around his waist. The man next left has a similar shirt with many patches on the sleeve. The ties around waists may serve to keep their shirts out of the liquid waste below. The man far left in suspenders over a wooly sweater or underwear has a small clay pipe. All men wear battered caps of thick cloth or leather, some with brims. The man far right wears a handkerchief over his nose and mouth (probably a very new worker). Some men hold sledge hammers or picks. Rubber was being used for boots by then but was not a common material yet. Leather could be treated with a mixture of oil, wax, turpentine, and pitch to be quite water-proof and more pliable, even before 1835. (Wiki.)
source: Kybalova, Ludmila, Olga Herbenova, and Milena Lamarova. Das Grosse Bilderlexicon der Mode. (Prague, Bertelsmann Lexicon, 1966). For additional authentic clothing of the poor in 1860, please view the BBC production: Victorian Slum House on YouTube.

caption: 1860-70 men. A poor immigrant’s work clothing
description: Beneath this cotton shirt is the man’s long-underwear top. The shirt opening only buttons half-way down the chest The shoulder seam rests down over the shoulder a few inches, as required by the standard shirt pattern seen elsewhere in this book. This modern reproduction shirt has fuller sleeves, gathered at the shoulder seam with rolled-up cuffs.
